MEMORANDUM:

- THE ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER -

Re: Educational Facilities - Oka Agency, Quebec.

The Oka Agency has an Indian population of 482 (Census, 1944) and of these, 262 are listed as members of the United Church of Canada and 160 as Roman Catholics, and 60 listed as other beliefs.

There are approximately 36 pupils of school age of the Roman Catholic faith. For a number of years, Catholic pupils have attended a white school in the village of Oka and the tuition fee of $5.00 per month per pupil has been paid by the department. The attached memorandum submitted by the Oka School Board reveals that the residents of Oka are urgently in need of additional school accommodation and that it is the intention of the School Board to provide this accommodation by the erection of a new school building during the summer of 1947. Unless accommodation can be secured in this building when erected for Indian children, the department will be called upon to erect an additional Indian day school at Oka for the accommodation of Roman Catholic pupils. The two Indian day schools at this agency - one in the village and one on the reserve - are operated under the auspices of the United Church of Canada.

I hesitate to recommend a $25,000.00 grant by the Government for the erection of the new school building, nor am I sure that we have statutory authority to make such a grant. It would be unwise, in my judgment, to become too closely linked up with the provincial educational authorities in the erection of public or separate schools. Such action on our part might lead to...
lead to constitutional complications - education as usually understood, being the sole responsibility of provincial governments. I would recommend, however, subject to the approval of the Minister, that we enter into an agreement with the Oka School Board for a fifteen-year period whereby we shall allow a tuition grant at the rate of $60.00 per pupil per annum and that this grant be paid quarterly, in the same manner as residential schools' grants are now paid and that the Secretary of the School Board at Oka be so notified.

Approved.

[Signature]

Director

13th February 1947.

La Commission Scolaire d'Oka

Educational Facilities for Indians of Oka Agency

Please find attached the proposals made concerning a grant of $25,000 towards the building of your new school. These proposals have been referred to our Minister. It is felt that under the present Indian Act, this Branch does not have the statutory authority to make such a grant.

However the Minister has approved the following proposals:

(a) That an agreement for a 15 year period be made between the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources and "La Commission Scolaire d'Oka" whereby

(1) The Indian Affairs Branch shall allow a tuition grant at the rate of $60.00 per pupil per annum based on the average annual attendance of each Indian pupil at the schools maintained and operated by "La Commission Scolaire d'Oka";

(2) "La Commission Scolaire d'Oka" shall render an attendance statement quarterly of such Indian pupils to the Indian Affairs Branch as the basis for the payment of this tuition grant.
Ottawa, February 19, 1947.

AGREEMENT made this day of A.D. 1947.

BETWEEN:

HIS MAJESTY KING GEORGE THE SIXTH in right of Canada, represented herein by the Minister of Mines and Resources, hereinafter called the "Minister"

-and-

OKA SCHOOL COMMISSION, of the Village of Oka, in the Province of Quebec, hereinafter called the "Commission".

WHEREAS the present educational facilities in the Village of Oka, in the Province of Quebec, are inadequate to accommodate the children of school age residing in the said Village and surrounding community;

AND WHEREAS the present lack of accommodation is caused by the fact that the present school building is small and inadequate and is used by both white and Indian children;

AND WHEREAS the Commission has made representations to the Minister for financial assistance in the matter of educating Indian children as such children are the responsibility of the Crown (Dominion);

AND WHEREAS the Minister is of opinion that there is not enough Indian children to warrant the erection of a special Indian School and that the financial assistance agreed upon in the terms hereinafter mentioned are fair and reasonable.

NOW THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that the parties hereto mutually covenant and agree as follows:

1. That this agreement shall commence on the 1st day of September 1947, and continue for the term of fifteen years from that date, subject to the terms, conditions and stipulations hereinafter expressed, that is to say:

2. The Minister shall pay to the Commission a tuition grant of Sixty Dollars ($60.00) per pupil per annum, if such pupil attends every prescribed school day of the academic year as determined by the Department of Education of the Province of Quebec.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6484, file 42020-3, part 5)

3. The Minister shall pay to the Commission a tuition grant of Six Dollars ($6.00) per pupil per month if such pupil attends fifty per cent or more of the prescribed school days of the academic month as determined by the Department of Education of the Province of Quebec.

4. The Minister shall not pay any tuition grant for any pupil who attends fewer than 50% of the prescribed days of the academic month as determined by the Department of Education of the Province of Quebec.

5. The Commission shall submit to the Director of Indian Affairs, Department of Mines and Resources, a certified monthly attendance statement of the Indian pupils in attendance at the school.

6. (Here should be included some provision for a one year notice of cancellation clause. I understand you have a clause on this subject which has proven satisfactory).

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties hereto have hereunto set their hands this day of 1947.

6. That in esse the rent hereby reserved or any part thereof is in arrear for the period of one calendar month, or in case default is made in the fulfilment of any covenant whether expressed or implied in these presents, on the part of the party of the second part, and is continued for the period of one calendar month, the party of the first part may enter upon and take possession of the demised land, (whether in the case of rent such rent shall have been lawfully demanded or not) and the term hereby granted shall thenceupon cease and determine.

7. That if the party of the second part shall make any assignment for the benefit of his creditors or take any benefit of any act that may be in force for bankrupt or insolvent debtors, or permit any writ of execution against his goods and chattels to be issued or remain in force after the first day of August in any year during the term hereby granted, the instalment of rent payable on the next ensuing first day of December shall then immediately become void and forfeit.

And it is agreed between the Parties hereto that the Party of the first part may terminate this lease or any renewal hereof at any time or in any year between November fifteenth and February fifteenth following, by giving notice in writing to the party of the second part by registered letter to the address hereinbefore set out.

Either party may, before the expiration of the full term of fifteen years aforesaid, effect determination or cession of this agreement on the thirteenth day of June in any year by giving to the other party notice in writing by registered letter of the intention to effect such determination or cession; such notice to be good and to take effect as aforesaid only if received on or before the first day of September next preceding the thirteenth day of June aforesaid.

C.A.T.C.
OTTAWA, May 12, 1947.

PROPOSAL FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Approval for an Agreement between HIS MAJESTY KING GEORGE THE SIXTH in right of Canada, represented by the Minister of Mines and Resources, and the Oka School Commission, of the Village of Oka, in the Province of Quebec, giving financial assistance to the Oka School Commission in the matter of educating Indian children.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the present educational facilities in the Village of Oka, in the Province of Quebec, are inadequate to accommodate the children of school age residing in the said Village and surrounding community;

THAT the present lack of accommodation is caused by the fact that the present school building is small and inadequate and is used by both white and Indian children;

THAT the Oka School Commission has made representations to the Minister of Mines and Resources for financial assistance in the matter of educating Indian children as such children are the responsibility of the Crown (Dominion);

THAT the Minister is of opinion that there are not enough Indian children to warrant the erection of a special Indian school and that the financial assistance agreed upon in the terms hereinafter mentioned is fair and reasonable.

The undersigned therefore has the honour to recommend:

THAT the approval of Your Excellency in Council be given for an agreement between HIS MAJESTY KING GEORGE THE SIXTH in right of Canada, represented herein by the Minister of Mines and Resources, hereinafter called the "Minister" and the OKA SCHOOL COMMISSION, of the Village of Oka, in the Province of Quebec, hereinafter called the "Commission," subject to the conditions as set forth in the attached agreement.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 20 MAY 1947.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 12th May, 1947, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That the present educational facilities in the Village of Oka, in the Province of Quebec, are inadequate to accommodate the children of school age residing in the said Village and surrounding community;

That the present lack of accommodation is caused by the fact that the present school building is small and inadequate and is used by both white and Indian children;

That the Oka School Commission has made representations to the Minister of Mines and Resources for financial assistance in the matter of educating Indian children as such children are the responsibility of the Crown (Dominion);

That the Minister is of opinion that there are not enough Indian children to warrant the erection of a special Indian school and that the financial assistance agreed upon in the terms hereinafter mentioned is fair and reasonable.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that Your Excellency may be pleased to authorize the continuation of the existing agreement between His Majesty King George the Sixth in right of Canada, represented therein by the Minister of Mines and Resources and the Oka School Commission, of the Village of Oka, in the Province of Quebec.

BUT DE L'ÉCOLE

Préparer des directrices et des officières qualifiées pour nos hôpitaux et nos Écoles d'infirmières; tel est le but que poursuit depuis 1834, année de sa fondation par les Sœurs Grises de Montréal, l'Institut Marguerite d'Youville, École supérieure pour Infirmières, affiliée à l'Université de Montréal.

ORGANISATION DE L'ENSEIGNEMENT

L'enseignement comprend un ensemble de cours — dont on trouvera le détail plus loin — répartis ordinairement en deux années. Mais tout dépend du degré d'instruction de l'élève à son entrée à l'Institut, de ses aptitudes pour l'étude et du temps qu'elle y consacre.

Les cours de la première année visant à la culture générale des élèves peuvent, indifféremment, précéder ou suivre le cours d'infirmière. Quant à ceux de seconde année, dits de culture professionnelle, ils sont exclusivement réservés aux infirmières graduées.

Ce programme d'études de deux années aboutit, normalement, au Baccalauréat ès sciences infirmières ou au Baccalauréat ès sciences de l'éducation des infirmières.

Aux infirmières qui n'osent prétendre au Baccalauréat, tout en désirant un supplément de formation, l'Institut offre des programmes variés où certains cours professionnels sont agencés de façon à ce que l'élève se spécialise et obtienne un Certificat en

a) Administration hospitalière;
b) Surveillance hospitalière;
c) Direction de l'École des infirmières;
d) Enseignement aux infirmières.

COURS D'ÉTÉ ET COURS EXTRA MUROS

Des cours sont donnés pendant les vacances d'été. Ils durent de 3 à 4 semaines. Le sujet de ces cours, l'endroit où ils se don-

nent et la date de leur ouverture varient selon les circonstances. On s'y inscrit dès qu'ils sont annoncés.

Afin d'assurer à un plus grand nombre d'infirmières les avantages d'une culture supérieure, l'Institut envoie ses professeurs donner l'un ou l'autre de ses cours là où l'on peut grouper au moins 15 infirmières graduées. On s'entend avec la Directrice pour le choix du cours, sa date d'ouverture et sa durée.

CONDITIONS D'ADMISSION

Inscription:

Les aspirantes doivent:

1° S'adresser à la Directrice de l'Institut, 1190, rue Guy, Montréal, qui leur fournira une formule d'inscription à remplir et retourner avant le 25 août.

2° Donner les noms et adresses: a) d'un proche parent; b) du dernier employeur. Les Religieuses donneront le nom et l'adresse de leur supérieure ainsi que l'office qu'elles remplissent dans leur Communauté au moment de leur inscription.

Conditions académiques:

1° Posséder, soit le diplôme supérieur français, soit le Certificat de Lettres et Sciences ou encore l'équivalent de la 11ème année du cours d'études primaires supérieures de la province de Québec.

2° Présenter une copie certifiée des matières étudiées et des points obtenus: a) aux études supérieures; b) au cours d'infirmière.

NOTE: Ces conditions sont absolument exigées des candidates aux grades universitaires; mais celles qui ne prétendent pas aux parchemins pourront être admises aux cours sans ces qualifications. Il est bien entendu, alors, qu'on ne leur accordera aucun « crédit » universitaire.
L'Institut se réserve le droit d'établir des équivalences pour des cours similaires à ceux de son programme que l'élève aurait suivis ailleurs.

ANNÉE SCOLAIRE

L'année scolaire commence dans la première semaine de septembre et finit dans la troisième semaine de juin. Elle se divise en deux termes dont le second commence avec février.

De la veille de Noël au lendemain du Jour des Rois exclusivement, et du Mercredi Saint au Lundi de Pâques inclusivement, les cours sont suspendus.

EXAMENS — DIPLÔMES

Pour avoir le droit de se présenter aux examens, il faut avoir suivi au moins 80% des cours; ce, pour chaque matière.

Pour prétendre au Baccalauréat, et même aux Certificats, il faut avoir conservé 60% des points sur chaque matière et une moyenne générale d'au moins 65%. Cependant, une élève qui n'aurait pas obtenu 60% sur une matière aura droit de la reprendre.

Quatre mois avant la graduation, l'aspirante au Baccalauréat présente une thèse sur un sujet choisi avec la Directrice de l'Institut. L'acceptation de cette thèse par le Conseil d'Administration est requise pour l'obtention du Baccalauréat.

La candidate qui conserve 90% des points a droit à la mention: TRES GRANDE DISTINCTION; 80% mérite: GRANDE DISTINCTION; 70%: DISTINCTION.

DÉBOURSÉS

L'inscription d'ensemble, donnant entrée à tous les cours de culture générale est de $180.00, payable en deux versements de $90.00 chacun, au début de chaque terme.

Même prix et même mode de paiement pour les cours de culture professionnelle.

Quant aux cours partiels, l'inscription est de $5.00 pour chaque série ou 15 heures de cours.

On demande $10.00 par année pour l'usage du laboratoire.

Examens:

Pour chaque examen final: 50 sous.

Diplômes:

a) le Certificat: $3.00;
b) le Baccalauréat: $15.00.

BOURSES ET PRÊTS

Par l'entremise de l'Association des Gardes-Malades de la Province, le Gouvernement Fédéral offre des bourses d'études aux infirmières désireuses de perfectionner leur formation professionnelle.

CONDITIONS À REMPLIR POUR OBTENIR UNE BOURSE

1° Présenter un certificat d'études de 11ème année ou son équivalent;

2° Être enregistrée dans l'Association des Gardes-Malades du Canada;

3° S'inscrire à l'Institut Marguerite d'Youville;

4° Après avoir été acceptée par l'Institut, présenter sa requête à l'Association des Gardes-Malades de la Province, le plus tôt possible après que les bourses ont été annoncées disponibles dans le journal des gardes-malades canadiennes: THE CANADIAN NURSE.

Des bourses d'études sont également octroyées sur demande, après entente avec la Direction de l'Institut Marguerite d'Youville, pour défrayer, en tout ou en partie, les cours extra-muros.
Quelques Écoles d'Infirmières, des Amicales, des Sociétés de bienfaisance offrent aussi, soit en don, soit en prêt, des bourses d'études aux infirmières. On obtiendra des renseignements à ce sujet, à l'Institut Marguerite d'Youville et en suivant les journaux, surtout les Revues professionnelles.

LOCAL DE L'ÉCOLE

L'Institut Marguerite d'Youville est situé dans la partie ouest de la Maison Mère des Sœurs Grises de Montréal. Le local en est organisé de façon à faciliter l'économie du temps, facteur essentiel du succès pour une étudiante.

La direction de l'Institut s'intéresse au logement et à la pension de ses élèves régulières, soit dans la maison même, soit à l'extérieur; mais à condition que demande lui en soit faite suffisamment à l'avance.

La bibliothèque, située à proximité des salles d'étude, comprend les plus récents volumes sur le nursing et l'administration hospitalière ainsi qu'un choix de livres et de revues sur la littérature, la philosophie, la chimie et autres matières au programme.

Dans un laboratoire très bien outillé, les élèves ont la facilité de faire toutes les expériences de chimie du programme.

LES COURS

Une série de cours comprend 15 leçons et un examen. Ce qui équivaut au « crédit » des écoles anglaises.

COURS DE CULTURE GÉNÉRALE

1. Philosophie:

   a) Minerve: Concept et terme,
      Jugement et proposition,
      Raisonnement et argumentation.

   LOGIQUE:

   b) Majeure: Éléments de la science: Universaux et principes. Modes de connaissance: définition et division. Méthodes.

   PSYCHOLOGIE:

   I — La vie en général.

   II — La vie en particulier.

   a) La vie végétative: opérations, puissances, âme.

   b) La vie sensitive: opérations, facultés, âme.

   c) La vie intellective: opérations, facultés.

   d) Existence, nature et propriétés de l'âme intellective.

   e) Union de l'âme et du corps.

   f) Origine de l'homme.

   CRITÉRIOLOGIE:

   a) Générale: La vérité, les états d'esprit vis-à-vis de la vérité, la certitude, l'évidence.

   b) Spéciale: La vérité dans les sens, La vérité dans l'intellect, Valeur du syllogisme et de l'induction, L'autorité divine et humaine.
MORALE:

a) Générale: la fin dernière, la loi, l'acte humain, la moralité, l'imputabilité, le mérite, la vertu.

b) Spéciale: application des principes de la morale générale à l'homme considéré comme individu (morale individuelle) et comme vivant en société (morale sociale). (16 séries de cours)

Titulaire: M. Antonio Précourt, p.s.s., D.Ph.

2. Littérature française:

Théorie générale de l'art d'écrire; principes; lois à observer, moyens à employer pour réussir; étude des procédés des grands écrivains. (4 séries de cours)

Application de ces principes aux divers types de travaux littéraires: thèse, conférence, dissertation, discours, compte-rendu. Nombreux exemples. (10 séries de cours)

Discussion et appréciation d'œuvres littéraires et scientifiques. (2 séries de cours)

Titulaire: Sœur M.-Rose Lacroix, s.g.m.

3. Anglais:

Application des règles de la grammaire; lectures et conversations appropriées; thèmes et versions; lettres, notions de littérature. (10 séries de cours)

Titulaire: Sœur Denise Lefebvre, s.g.m.

4. Physique:

Les sciences physiques prennent, de jour en jour, une part plus grande dans les applications médicales. Aussi, ce cours procure aux élèves des connaissances précieuses qui leur permettent de comprendre le fonctionnement des appareils en usage dans les hôpitaux. (2 séries de cours)

Titulaire: Sœur M.-Rose Lacroix, s.g.m.

5. Chimie:

Notions générales de chimie: révision, principaux corps simples et composés de chimie minérale en insistant sur leurs relations avec la physiologie et la thérapeutique.

CHIMIE ORGANIQUE: les hydrocarbures et leurs principaux produits de substitution — fonctions. Les glucides. Les lipides. Les protides.

CHIMIE BIOLOGIQUE: Les diastases. Les enzymes. La circulation, les échanges cellulaires. Les aliments. Le lait. Les sucs digestifs. (2 séries de cours)

Titulaire: Sœur M.-Rose Lacroix, s.g.m.

6. Apologétique:

a) La Religion:

Existence, nature et action de Dieu. Religion, révélation et critères de la révélation.

Les principales religions non chrétiennes. Les sources de la Révélation. Preuves de la divinité du christianisme. (2 séries de cours)

b) Le Christianisme:

Institution de l'Église. Notes et prérogatives de l'Église. Constitution de l'Église. Rapport de l'Église et de l'État.

Accord de la foi avec la raison et les sciences. Réponses aux objections tirées de l'Écriture Sainte, aux objections des Protestants et aux objections populaires. (2 séries de cours)

Titulaire: M. Antonio Précourt, p.s.s.
COURS PROFESSIONNELS

7. Morale médicale:
   Exigences de la Morale chrétienne par rapport à la chirurgie,
   la médecine, l'obstétrique et les maladies mentales. (1 série de cours)
   Titulaire: R. Père Henri Samson, s.j.

8. Histoire de la pédagogie:
   Idées générales sur les questions essentielles de l'éducation
   et le développement des institutions scolaires. Évolution des
   méthodes d'enseignement. Énonciation des principes et leur ap-
   plication. Recherches des ouvrages à consulter. (2 séries de cours)
   Titulaire: Sœur Jeanne S.-Lou's, s.g.m.

9. Histoire de la profession d'infirmière:
   Le soin des malades de l'antiquité à nos jours. Influence de
   la religion, de la société et des organisations professionnelles.
   Progrès et activités modernes de la profession. Idéaux à proposer
   aux infirmières. (2 séries de cours)
   Titulaire: Sœur Jeanne S.-Lou's, s.g.m.

10. Sociologie:
    Grâce aux données de l'ethnologie comparée, de l'archéolo-
    gie, de l'histoire, de la philosophie, de la révélation, on établit
    l'échelle des valeurs dans la société. On étudie les différents ma-
    laises dont souffre notre société actuelle et on suggère des re-
    medes, en respectant l'échelle des valeurs que nous avons établie.
    (2 séries de cours)
    Titulaire: M. Amédée Allard, p.s.s.

11. Pédagogie appliquée aux infirmières:
    Observation de classes modèles; préparation de leçons et
    enseignement de cours professionnels par chacune des élèves.
    Critique des leçons. (2 séries de cours)
    Titulaire: Sœur Denise Lefebvre, s.g.m.

12. Psychologie de l'infirmière:
    Application de la psychologie à l'éducation de l'intelligence,
    de la volonté, du caractère, en un mot, de toute la personnalité
    de l'infirmière dans les diverses situations de la vie. (3 séries de cours)
    Titulaire: Sœur Denise Lefebvre, s.g.m.

13. Organisation des programmes d'études:
    Rôle du programme dans l'éducation; contenu et disposition
    des matières du programme; ordre à suivre; division des heures
    d'études, etc. (2 séries de cours)
    Titulaire: Sœur Denise Lefebvre, s.g.m.

14. Problèmes de morale professionnelle:
    Idéal moral de l'infirmière. Nécessité de la science profes-
    sionnelle. Vertus d'état. Qualités naturelles et surhumaines des
    dirigeantes. Initiatives légitimes. Solidarité professionnelle. L'in-
    firmière dans les cadres de l'Action Catholique. Étude et apprê-
    tation des livres traitant de la formation de l'infirmière. Dis-
    cussion des problèmes particuliers à la profession. (2 séries de cours)
    Titulaire: Sœur Jeanne S.-Lou's, s.g.m.

15. Hygiène mentale:
    Objectif de l'hygiène mentale. Définition du psychisme. Part
    de l'hérédité et du milieu. Vie affective. Rôle considérable de la
    volonté. Force de la religion. Méthodes et principes généraux
    pour la prévention des maladies mentales chez l'enfant, l'adoles-
    cent, l'adulte. Applications pratiques. (2 séries de cours)
    Titulaire: Sœur Jeanne S.-Lou's, s.g.m.

16. Méthodologie générale:
    Principes généraux; procédés spéciaux; méthodes d'ensei-
    gnement appliquées à l'école des infirmières; enseignement par:

17. Méthodologie spéciale aux infirmières:
Application des connaissances acquises dans la méthodologie générale; marche à suivre dans les leçons; matériel d'enseignement; sources de références. (2 séries de cours)
Titulaire: Sœur Denise Lefebvre, s.g.m.

18. Enseignement clinique:
Méthodes d'enseignement auprès des malades, par procédés de: a) conférences; b) cliniques; c) étude de cas, etc. (2 séries de cours)
Titulaire: Sœur Denise Lefebvre, s.g.m.

19. Principes d'éducation:
Étude des grands principes qui doivent guider toute éducatrice professionnelle dans la formation physique, intellectuelle, morale, sociale et religieuse des élèves-infirmières. Travaux de recherche sur les tendances actuelles en éducation des infirmières. Applications pratiques. (2 séries de cours)
Titulaire: Sœur Denise Lefebvre, s.g.m.

20. Organisation des écoles d'infirmières:
Objectifs de l'École; organisation: matérielle, scientifique, sociale et religieuse. Budget. Relations de l'École avec l'Hôpital. Affiliations. Personnel enseignant. (2 séries de cours)
Titulaire: Sœur Mance Décaray, s.g.m.

21. Organisation et administration de l'hôpital:
Définition et objectif de l'hôpital. Classification des hôpitaux. Construction. Principes d'organisation et d'administration. Étude des trois grandes divisions de l'organisation de l'hôpital.

savoir: DIRECTION, ADMINISTRATION, FONCTIONNEMENT. (3 séries de cours)
Titulaire: Sœur Jeanne S. Lou's, s.g.m.

22. Organisation des services hospitaliers:
Choix, qualifications, attributions des personnels: Bureau d'admission, Bureau médical, Archives médicales. Service social. Visites d'observation, travaux de recherches, discussions. (2 séries de cours)
Titulaire: Sœur Jeanne S. Lou's, s.g.m.

23. Surveillance hospitalière:
Ce cours prépare la future hospitalière à réaliser son double objectif: 1° Maintenir et améliorer la qualité du service de nursing; 2° Promouvoir l'avancement du personnel infirmier. (2 séries de cours)
Titulaire: Sœur Jeanne S. Lou's, s.g.m.

24. Stages:
Suitant les aptitudes particulières de l'étudiante, un stage déterminé lui est assigné dans un hôpital reconnu, sous la direction d'hospitalières expérimentées. L'étudiante doit faire un rapport détaillé de ses expériences et de ses observations. Ce stage équivaut à... (2 séries de cours)

25. Finances et comptabilité:
a) Comptabilité: Revue de la théorie générale de comptabilité. Application aux hôpitaux. Préparation et présentation des états financiers. Éléments de vérification et de contrôle. (2 séries de cours)
b) Finances: Organisation et administration financières des hôpitaux. (1 série de cours)
Titulaire: Sœur Berthe Dorais, s.g.m.

Ce cours consiste en des visites d'observation et un stage pratique dans un service social modèle, accompagné de discussions en présence du Directeur du service. (1 série de cours)

Notre profession élève son programme d'études à un niveau supérieur, offrant ainsi une base solide pour les infirmières qui se dirigeront vers les postes de commande. Afin de répondre aux exigences actuelles, l'INSTITUT MARGUERITE D'YOUVILLE donne des cours de culture générale et de perfectionnement professionnel.

**BUT DE L'ECOLE**

Préparer à l'enseignement, à l'administration et à la surveillance, dans les écoles d'infirmières, ainsi que dans les hôpitaux.

**PLAN GENERAL DES COURS**

I. BACCALAUREAT ES SCIENCES INFIRMIERES

Deux années d'études en plus des trois ans du cours d'infirmière sont exigées pour l'obtention du Baccalauréat ès sciences infirmières.

A noter que la première année (année préparatoire) peut précéder le cours d'infirmière. Dans ce cas, celui-ci est abrégé de huit mois, dans quelques écoles.

Cette première année est consacrée à la culture générale. L'élève s'applique à l'étude de la philosophie, de la littérature française, de l'anglais, de la physique et de la chimie. Les cours de religion et d'apologétique se continuent pendant les deux années.

Quant aux cours de seconde année, dits de culture professionnelle, consulter l'annuaire de l'Institut pour plus de détails.

II. CERTIFICATS

Quatre à huit mois d'études intensives conduisent aux certificats suivants :

A. EN SURVEILLANCE HOSPITALIERE — pour les infirmières responsables de services dans les hôpitaux.

**Cours requis**

1. Apologétique  
2. Sociologie  
3. Problèmes de morale professionnelle  
4. Hygiène mentale  
5. Organisation et administration de l'hôpital  
6. Surveillance hospitalière  
7. Enseignement clinique  
8. Stage en milieu hospitalier  
9. Notions générales d'hygiène publique  
10. Organisation des services hospitaliers

B. EN ENSEIGNEMENT AUX INFIRMIÈRES — pour les institutrices

**Cours requis**

1. Apologétique  
2. Sociologie  
3. Hygiène mentale  
4. Psychologie de l'éducation  
5. Problèmes de morale professionnelle  
6. Méthodologie générale  
7. Pédagogie appliquée aux infirmières (observations et pratique d'enseignement)  
8. Organisation du programme d'études  
9. Direction des écoles d'infirmières  
10. Enseignement clinique

C. EN ENSEIGNEMENT CLINIQUE — pour les directrices et les institutrices d'enseignement clinique dans les services hospitaliers.

**Cours requis**

1. Apologétique  
2. Sociologie  
3. Problèmes de morale professionnelle  
4. Organisation et administration de l'hôpital  
5. Principes et méthodes d'enseignement clinique  
6. Hygiène mentale  
7. Direction de l'enseignement clinique  
8. Méthodologie générale  
9. Observation pratique d'enseignement clinique  
10. Psychologie pédagogique

D. EN ADMINISTRATION DES ÉCOLES D'INFIRMIÈRES — pour les directrices.

**Cours requis**

1. Apologétique  
2. Problèmes de morale professionnelle  
3. Sociologie  
4. Hygiène mentale  
5. Psychologie de l'éducation  
6. Législation sociale  
7. Finance  
8. Organisation et administration de l'hôpital  
9. Organisation et direction des écoles d'infirmières  
10. Organisation du programme d'études  
11. Principes d'éducation ou philosophie pédagogique

Ce cours doit être suivi d'un STAGE dans une école d'infirmières approuvée par l'Université de Montréal et choisie par l'Institut Marguerite d'Youville.

E. DIRECTION DE L'HÔPITAL — pour toute personne responsable de l'administration de l'hôpital ou de services hospitaliers.

**Cours requis**

1. Apologétique  
2. Sociologie  
3. Hygiène mentale  
4. Sciences sociales  
5. Problèmes de morale professionnelle  
6. Organisation et administration de l'hôpital  
7. Législation sociale  
8. Organisation des services hospitaliers  
9. Surveillance hospitalière  
10. Finance  
11. Direction de l'enseignement clinique (au besoin)

Ce cours doit être suivi d'un STAGE en administration, dans un hôpital approuvé.
COURS POST-SCOLAIRES

L'Institut Marguerite d'Youville, conjointement avec des hôpitaux universitaires, donne des cours post-scolaires dans les diverses spécialités cliniques : MEDECINE, CHIRURGIE, PEDIATRIE, OBSTETRIQUE, PSYCHIATRIE.

La durée de ces cours est de six à huit mois.

COURS SPECIAUX

Pour les infirmières diplômées, en service à l'hôpital ou à l'école d'infirmières.

Le programme des cours peut être organisé de façon à favoriser, dans la mesure du possible, les infirmières religieuses et laïques qui désirent se perfectionner tout en continuant leur travail.

COURS EXTRA-MUROS

Dans le but de promouvoir l'avancement du nursing, l'Institut envoie ses professeurs donner des cours, sur demande des Directrices ou des présidentes de districts, là où l'on peut grouper environ 15 infirmières, religieuses ou laïques.

OUVERTURE DES COURS

L'ouverture des cours est fixée au mercredi de la deuxième semaine de septembre. Les inscriptions au cours régulier doivent se faire, autant que possible, avant le 24 août.

OCTROI DE BOURSES

L'Aide à la jeunesse accorde des bourses, n'excédant pas $300.00, aux infirmières qui désirent poursuivre leurs études jusqu'au CERTIFICATS ou BACCALAUREAT.

L'Association provinciale des infirmières ainsi que l'association locale (District No 11) offrent des bourses de $300.00 environ, dans le même but.

Celles qui veulent bénéficier de ces bourses devront s'assurer de leur admission, dans le plus bref délai possible, à l'INSTITUT MARGUERITE D'YOUVILLE.

Miss Therese Cree of Oka, aged 17, accompanied by her mother recently applied for a grant in order to enable her to attend the Institut Marguerite d'Youville Montreal, Que., in order to take up nursing. The minimum being 18 years old. She was then advised to enter the above institution where she would get the best advanced training for the profession she intends to take.

You will find herewith some correspondence between Therese and the Institut Marguerite d'Youville. Also some prospectus which have been sent, giving details as to the curriculum and the price of the courses together with that of the board.

You will note that the cost of the studies would be of $205.00 and that of the board of $35.00 per month, for a total of $555.00 for the 10 months.

This amount is rather prohibitive if we take into consideration the fact that the parents would be unable to contribute in the amount of $100.00 only.

Please let me have your comments in this case.

(Frs. Brisebois)

I had a visit this morning from Mrs. Henri Vincent of Oka.

She states that she spoke to you July last with reference to her two children, Raymond and Jean. The former has been placed in a school where the cost of $34.00 a month and the latter in a school where the cost is $19.00 a month.

Mrs. Vincent informed me that she is a widow and receives a pension but did not state the amount of the pension nor from whom she receives it. She expressed the opinion that the Department should pay at least half the cost of the two children's education in the schools at which they have been placed.

I pointed out to her that this matter should have been brought to our attention either in July or August. I also reminded her that in paying a pension it was the intention to enable a widowed mother to maintain her home. She stated that the pension was not sufficiently large to enable her to purchase a home.

Please let me have a report regarding this case, stating what assistance, if any, you think we should give.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant enclosing an account in the amount of $287.75 from the Institut Marguerite d'Youville, in the case of Therese Cree of Oka.

In reply I wish to say that the parents of Therese Cree were notified of your decision contained in your letter of August 26th last, but with the help of a relative decided to place the girl at the above institution as she had passed her entrance examination with high marks.

However it would appear that the amount of the tuition and board which is over $400.00 per year will be too much for them to pay, according to Mrs. Cree, as they have several other children and Mr. Cree, who is a carpenter has been out of work since a few weeks due to ill health. Mrs. Cree stated that she saved the sum of $200.00 towards the payment of the tuition and board of Therese and requested a similar amount from the Branch if at all possible.

Communication with the Institut revealed that Therese, who is taking a special course to prepare her to take up nursing, is not only a good pupil but an exceptionally good one who has obtained the highest marks regularly.

Owing to the above circumstances I would kindly ask you to take her case into consideration it being understood that no further help will be asked after this year as she will enter a Hospital for her nursing course which she could not do this year being a younger than the minimum age required.

/ year /

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Transportation of Indian Children attending the Oka Village Schools.

For the past two years, as you are aware, the R.C., indian pupils living in the country are travelling daily to the village to attend School.

An Indian named Jos. Richard, Jr., is hired to take them to and from the Country what he is doing with a light truck when the roads are opened and with a team and sleigh when the roads are closing.

Mr. Richard is using an ordinary uncovered sleigh which he owns. However when the wind is high and in cold weather younger children do not attend or miss more school than they should on account of lack of proper equipment.

We have found a completely covered sleigh (double) which was formerly used to transport the Professors to and from the Agricultural College at a price of $35.00. This sleigh is in fair condition and would meet our requirements. It is considered that this acquisition would improve the transportation of the children.

Please let me know if this purchase can be made. It is understood that in the event of Richard discontinuing to transport the children to the Schools that the above would remain our property.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th instant relative to voucher no. 25 for transportation of children to the Oka Convent and College, which was made out at $3.00 per day for December 1948, instead of $2.50 as for previous months.

In reply I wish to inform that Mr. Richard, the Indian who is doing this work has requested to be paid an extra $0.50 per day for the winter months when he often had to use his team instead of his car for the transportation. If you refer to the accounts sent for the corresponding months last year you will note that the same arrangement had been made.

In view of the conditions prevailing at Oka with regard to the roads it is considered that the charge of $3.00 per day is reasonable for the winter months, it being understood that only $2.50 per day will be charged from April 1st, next.

Caughnawaga, Que., July 22, 1949.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.,

Re:- Tuition grant, Oka Agency.

An application for a grant on behalf of Serge Johnson an Oka Indian, has recently been made by his mother for him to attend the College of Montreal, Sherbrooke st., west, in order to start a College course.

Serge has for the past five years arrived first in his respective classes at the St. Rene Academy at Oka and is considered as a brilliant pupil who is very studious.

A grant at the above institution would have to amount to $275.00 and his brothers who are employed would furnish the difference. The total cost of studies amounts to $400.00 per year.

Herewith enclosed is a letter from the Principal of the Oka College where Serge graduated this year.

Please take this request into consideration.

(Frs. Brisebois)

AFFILIATION

In establishing and maintaining the plan of affiliation, the authorities of the CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY OF AMERICA have especially in mind the first part of Article 71, Section 2, of the Statutes of the University as approved by the Sacred Congregation of Seminaries and Universities. This article reads: "Colleges, Seminaries, and other Catholic Institutions may, without prejudice to their autonomy, be affiliated to the University by the Rector and the Academic Senate, upon the fulfillment of conditions to be prescribed by said Rector and Senate."

Certain minimum requirements are necessary for the proper maintenance of an institution of any kind, but the main emphasis is placed on the administrators' understanding of the purpose of their foundation as a Catholic institution, on their zeal, and on the resources at their command to enable the institution to attain the aims proposed.

SYSTEM OF EDUCATION

Saint Joseph High is under the administration of the Clerics of Saint Viator (C.S.V.), a body of religious teachers who devote themselves to the work of Catholic education. This Congregation founded a century ago, is international in scope, conducting all types of schools in Belgium, France, Spain, China, Canada and the United States. Into the history of the success of Saint Joseph's have gone the experiences of men consecrated to the work of education in various parts of the world during the past hundred years.

The atmosphere and environment of the School, the planning of each day's program, the daily companionship of vigorous manly boys, and the associations with men whose lives are devoted to school work, are indispensable factors in the preparation of a boy for higher education. The advantages of these factors and many others are offered by the School for the benefit of the student during his high school days.
RELIGIOUS INSTRUCTION

However important the mental development of a student may be, his moral development is of still greater importance. Without a conscience, an educated man is a menace to society. Religious education which alone can develop and strengthen the will and induce good habits, is of prime importance at Saint Joseph's. In addition to the formal courses in Religion covering the whole field of Christian Dogma and Morals, obligatory on all students, Holy mass is celebrated daily in the students' Chapel; Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament, Devotions to the Sacred Heart and to Our Blessed Lady, and other liturgical functions are held at frequent intervals. Moreover the Sodalities which function in the School and the Catholic Action Movement aim at developing a spirit of virile piety in the students.

PERSONAL INTEREST

St. Joseph's looks upon its course of instruction and its system of discipline as only secondary to its chief aim—the formation of good character. The Faculty do not isolate themselves from the boys. The relations between them are personal. An atmosphere of frankness and manliness between the students and the Faculty gives to the school an invaluable aid for successful work. Character training is not confined to school hours. On the athletic field, in the clubs, in study, in the library, in every activity the program of personal attention and mutual approach to problems is carried on the develop interests apart from their lessons. They meet minds more mature than their own. They are made to realize that they have a share of responsibility in their character development. In these personal contacts, judgment and good habits are consolidated to mold the men of tomorrow.

GUIDANCE

Educational, vocational and spiritual guidance are featured as an integral part of the educational program at Saint Joseph's. Spiritual counsel is imparted by the Chaplains. The head Chaplain supervises the religious activities of the Student Body. Educational guidance is available to the student at all times. Vocational guidance is available upon request. All students are required to participate in a testing program which furnishes Counselors with data for educational and vocational guidance. Standard tests are used in this program.

PRINCIPLES, AIMS, IDEALS

SAINT JOSEPH'S is a boarding school for Franco-American students. The principles underlying the system of education functioning at SAINT JOSEPH'S are based on the solid philosophy of the Catholic Church which makes up the basis of all education. In upholding these principles ST JOSEPH'S subscribes to the belief that education in its truest sense is not merely intellectual achievement, but the development of every phase in a boy's life — the training of his soul, mind and body.

To attain its scolastic aims, SAINT JOSEPH HIGH endeavors to develop habits of industry and accuracy in study, a high regard for scholarship, and the spirit of willingness to conquer difficulties through perseverance. Every effort is made to promote health and physical development. Throughout the year the boys participate in all kinds of organized athletic sports and games under the supervision of capable directors. Moral training is secured by imparting a knowledge of religious truth, by developing a high regard for the gifts of faith, and by instilling the principles of Christian virtues.

The boys of SAINT JOSEPH'S must have lofty ideals in order to adjust themselves to the norm set by the principles and aims of the school.

It is through such channels that SAINT JOSEPH HIGH hopes to guide its students by providing those moral, mental and physical standards which successfully prepare them not merely for higher education but for life itself.

LOCATION, ACCOMMODATIONS

Saint Joseph's is located at Berthierville, along the St. Lawrence River, fifty miles north of Montreal, on the highway to Quebec. Its location is easy of access either by train, bus or ferry. The School accommodates three hundred resident students. The cafeteria and laundry services are taken care of by the Sisters of the Sacred Heart of Ottawa. The Board of Underwriters have fully approved the modern alarm and fire sprinklers systems. A physician is attached to the School and may be consulted at any hour of the day. Consulting specialists and convenient hospital service are close at hand.
REGULATIONS GOVERNING ADMISSION

Candidates for admission to the Freshman Class must be graduates of an approved grammar school and present a certificate of admission to high school. The record of the candidate's scholastic achievement ought to be on file before registration. A knowledge of the French language is not required of the applicant, but the study of French is a requirement in the four years of high school.

ADMISSION TO ADVANCED STANDING

Students who apply for the upper classes must present a transcript of their high school record with an official statement of honorable dismissal. Credit will be reckoned according to St. Joseph's curricular requirements and the certificating grades of the institution from which transfer is made.

Regulations Governing Scholastic Standing

Grades are determined monthly on the basis of supervised written tests. Also written examinations are given at the end of terms. Final grades are calculated by combining the monthly test marks with the examination mark of the end of term. The passing grade is 60%. Recommendations are not issued to students in any subject in which they have not achieved a grade of 70%.

CREDITS

The school year is made up of two semesters, each of eighteen weeks. One credit in one subject implies an aggregate of 120 hours of class work in that subject. Half credits may be granted for one semester of work. No credit is given for an incomplete semester. Sixteen credits are required for graduation.

PROMOTION

To be promoted to a higher class, the student at St. Joseph's must obtain a general final average of 60%, on the monthly and final examinations.

DIPLOMAS

The Saint Joseph High Diploma is awarded to the graduate who fulfills all the requirements of the School and obtains a good average in Fourth Year High at St. Joseph's.

The present plan of affiliation does not require the taking of formal examinations from the University. A secondary school Diploma is however issued by the University to those students in the senior class who have fulfilled the requirements of the School and, in addition thereto, pass successfully comprehensive examinations in seven subjects, namely: Religion, English, Algebra, Geometry, French or Latin, History and a Natural Science. Students are not considered as candidates to the above University examinations unless they obtain an average of sixty percent on those subjects during the months prior to the taking of the examinations.

SCHOLARSHIPS

Scholarship grants are for a period of one year. Information about available scholarships may be obtained by writing to the Director of Scholarships.

DISCIPLINE

The educational system at Saint Joseph's aims at the formation of character. Accordingly, the Discipline is considerate but firm especially when the reputation of the student body or the School is concerned. Matters of discipline are supervised by the Prefect of Discipline.
DISMISSAL

The Administration reserves the right to dismiss at any time a student who refuses to comply with the regulations of the School.

OUTFIT

The school outfit is loaned for the year. This is to be worn on special occasions only. The student may wear any color suit. A suit coat must always be worn in chapel. The wearing of overalls and dungarees is prohibited.

Boarders must be provided with an overcoat, heavy underwear for the winter, pyjamas, overshoes and rubbers, towels, soap, mirror, comb, toothbrush and other toilet articles. All clothes should be marked with the student's name and enrollment number.

STUDENT EXPENSES

After the student has been notified that he has been accepted for enrollment, he will be required to make registration. A fee of $5.00 is payable at the time of this registration. All fees are to be paid in advance, upon receiving a monthly invoice sent by the Bursar. The Administration reserves the right to suspend any student whose parents do not fulfill the obligation of paying fees at the prescribed time. To obtain transfers, reports, promotion certificates or diplomas, all financial indebtedness must be settled with the School.

## DESCRIPTION OF COURSES

These outlines are intentionally concise and contain only those topics recognized as being essential to the courses.

### FIRST YEAR HIGH

**Religion** — Laux, A course in Religion, Part One.

Doctrinal theme: God is a living Father. Moral theme: Obedience.

The Christian Ideal and the Commandments.

**English Literature:** Deferrari, Brentano, Sheehy, Joy in Reading.

The study of literature in the first year of high school should serve to stimulate the student's interest in good reading and to acquaint him with the fundamental types of literature. The study in class of simple types chosen with a view to interesting young students in the narrative poem, the drama, prose fiction, and the lyric should serve as its purpose the enjoyment and understanding of great literature.

**Reading:** Adventure. Achievement. The joy of living. The beauty of the world. The inevitable conflict. The life of Grace. Personal ideals. Man and his work. Home and family. The love of country. Man and society.

**English grammar and rhetoric** — Canby & Opdycke, Good English, Book One.

The purpose of the study of grammar and rhetoric is corrective as well as constructive for both oral and written expression. The structure of composition, points of good usage, and the rules of grammar should be illustrated through short themes.

**French Grammar and Literature** — Smith, French — Book One.

Elements of Grammar: definite lessons to carry the pupil only up to a brief and preliminary presentation of the subjunctive. Vocabulary and idioms; Cultural Background: Selections selections in French chosen to show French Character through pleasing pictures of folk-ways and customs; through stories of great deeds, persons, and epochs of French history, through an emphasis on the high achievements of French art and literature; also essays, written in English, to furnish a panoramic view of French activities and background.

**Latin** — Smith & Thompson, First Year Latin,

Thompson & Peters, Latin Workbook to accompany textbook.

**Reading:** Classical selections.

Vocabulary and Grammar: Fundamental forms of noun and verb. The principles of Syntax fundamental to an understanding of easy Latin reading; Cultural Background: Roman Life and Civilization; Latin Mottoes.
BUSINESS ARITHMETIC — Van Tuyl, Practical Arithmetic.

To cover the ground described by any standard textbook of advanced course in practical arithmetic.

ALGEBRA — Hall & Knight, Elementary Algebra.

Factors. Fractions. Simultaneous equations of the first degree, involving two or three unknown quantities.

BIOLOGY — Brother H. Charles, F.S.C., Biology.

Brother H. Charles, F.S.C., Laboratory Directions.

Animal life. Plant life. Inter-relationship of plant and animal life. Study of minute structures. General and special functioning. Human biology.

TYPEWRITING — Degan, Manual of Natural Touch and Speed Typewriting.

Explanation of the fundamental principles. Elementary fingering exercises for mastering the keyboard. Rhythmic drills. Individual practice for speed.

SHORTHAND — Gregg, Gregg Shorthand.

Thirty-six units.

SECOND YEAR HIGH

RELIGION — Laux, A course in Religion, Part Two.

Doctrinal theme: Grace and supernatural life. Moral theme. Cooperation with grace brings highest self development. Grace. Prayer. The Sacraments. Indulgences. The Sacramentals. Religious ceremonies and practices.

ENGLISH LITERATURE — Defferrari, Brentano, Sheekey, Appreciation through Literature.

In the second year of high school a study of literature through types is continued, with emphasis on structure, content, style, the development of critical judgment, and literary taste.

Readings: The short story. The novel. Narrative poetry. Biography and the narrative of experience. The literature of the journalist. The letter. Lyric poetry. Choral reading. The essay. The drama.

ENGLISH GRAMMAR and RHETORIC — Canby & Opdycke, Good English, Book Two.

The study of grammar and rhetoric is stressed. The purpose is corrective as well as constructive for both oral and written expression. The structure of composition, points of good usage, and the rules of grammar are illustrated through short themes.

FRENCH GRAMMAR and LITERATURE — Smith, French — Book Two.

Grammar. Vocabulary and Idiom. Cultural background. Readings.

LATIN — Scudder, Second Year Latin.

Herzberg, Classical Myths.

Vocabulary and Grammar: First Year Rapid Review Lessons; Intuitive Study of word forms and syntax. The Study of Time. Life of Caesar from the Vag Records (Reality simplified). Characterization of Caesar: Organization and Working of Caesar's Army. Selections from Books II-VII of the Gallic War. The Battle of Pharselus from Caesar's Civil War. The Argonauts.

ALGEBRA — Hall & Knight, Elementary Algebra.

The following course contains those topics which are recognized as forming the essential basis for further work in mathematics and other sciences and for the practical needs of the educated person in everyday life.

Factoring and its applications. Powers. Roots. Surds. Ratio and Proportion. Quadratic equations. Quadratic equations in two unknowns. Theory of quadratics. Indices. Logarithms. Surd Equations. Graphs.

AMERICAN HISTORY — Wilson, American History.

The purpose of the study of History is to develop in the student an active appreciation of his individual and collective, civic and social responsibilities.

Evolution of the American nation. Rise and progress of democratic ideals. History of the foreign relations of the U.S.A. The economic and social development of the country. Evolution of the government with its great civic problems. History of the nation as well as a world power. Catholic contribution to American life. French explorers' discoveries. Baltimore's colony of toleration. Indian missions. Settlements of the Spanish and the French Catholic patriots during the Revolution. Leaders among Churchmen and laymen. Establishment of the Church. Immigration from Catholic countries.

TYPEWRITING — Degan, Manual of Natural Touch and Speed Typewriting.

Letter forms. Margins. Addressing envelopes. Cachets. Tabulating. Billing. Cutting stencils. Manifolding. Statement work. Manuscripts. Exercises for increase of speed to 60 words per minute on straight copy.

SHORTHAND — Gregg, Speed Studies.

Speed studies to write at least one hundred words per minute. Demonstration. Reading from shorthand forms. Dictation. Vocabulary building. Taking dictation for typewriting.
THIRD YEAR HIGH

RELIGION — Laux, A course in Religion — Part Three.

Doctrinal theme: Humanity and divinity of Jesus, Jesus as Redeemer, as ideal Man, as way to God. Moral theme: Imitation and re-living the life of Jesus. The Apostles' Creed.

ENGLISH LITERATURE — Deferrari, Brentano, Sheekey, The American Profile.

A survey of American literature and its progressive stages is an important phase in high school literature. The directness and freshness of this literature, and its nearness to the student's own life, make it attractive to young people. In the study of American literature it is well to keep in mind the development of the democratic spirit, and to point out the ideals which characterize so much of the earlier work. The distinctive part played by American literature in the development of fiction, the short story, and the novel, should not be overlooked.

Readings: Colonial period. Revolutionary period. The early National period. The Advancing Frontier. The reign of Realism. The contemporary scene.

FRENCH — Travis and Travis, Cours Moyen de Français. De Sauze, Contes gais.

Grammar. Parsing and Analysis. Composition. Readings. Conversation.

LATIN — Kelsey & Meinecke, Third Year Latin.

Kelsey & Meinecke. Exercises in Prose Composition.

Cicero: Passages from Sallust; Conspiracy of Catiline, the poetical and romantic; Letters from Livy, and the fascinating Letters of Pliny. These selections from Cicero's writing are chosen and organized so as to present a great variety of style, and at the same time provide a unified picture of his life and thought reconstructed in the form of Prose Compositions. An aim in this course is to associate ancient and modern life and to make the study of Cicero real and tangible. In this view parallels are constantly employed in the form of oral discussions and themes.

ANCIENT & MEDIEVAL HISTORY — Hayes, Moon & Wayland, World History.

For the Catholic school it is essential that the pupil be brought to understand the share that the Church has had in shaping the world's history, by preaching the gospel, civilizing various peoples, preserving the treasures of ancient learning, framing systems of law, and encouraging industry and art. In particular, emphasis should be laid on what was accomplished during the Middle Ages; the advancement of learning, the improvement of economic conditions; the establishment of organizations to care for all forms of suffering, and the cooperation of Church and State for the common welfare.

Beginning of Civilization; Classical Civilization in the Greek City-States; Classical Civilization in the Roman Empire; The Classical to Christian Civilization; Christian Civilization in Medieval Europe; The Expansion of Europe; Uplheaval in State and Church in Europe.

PLANE GEOMETRY — Hall & Stevens, A School Geometry.

The purpose of the course in plane geometry is to acquaint the student with some of the fundamental tools of geometry, to lead him to discover in an informal manner some of the simpler geometric facts, and gradually to convince him of the necessity of a formal proof to make his conclusions watertight. The student should learn how to think logically, and systematically through the solution of numerous exercises, including construction problems. Problems involving the direct applications of geometric principles to incidents occurring in daily life are also used.

Introduction. Rectilinear figures. The circle. Proportion and Similarity. Area of Polygons. Regular Polygons and the Circle.

PHYSICS — Millikan, Gale & Coyle, New Elementary Physics.

Cushing. A laboratory Guide and Workbook.

The purpose of the course in physics is to help the student analyze, interpret, and understand his environment, changing physical environments to the end that he may be a more intelligent consumer, make better use of his leisure time, and participate more intelligently in his role as citizen. Much of the material involved in this course has been used in a casual way at least, part of every student's experience. Throughout the whole course, the teacher makes reference to these experiences in household and industrial applications of physical laws as a foundation for further study.

Introduction. Mechanics. Heat. Magnetism. Static Electricity. Current Electricity. Sound. Light.

Several experiments are performed by the student. The work is so distributed as to give a wide range of observation and practice.

BOOKKEEPING — Belding, Greene & Beech, Applied Bookkeeping and Accounting.

Beech & Graham Bruce, Drill Exercises in Bookkeeping.

Uses of ordinary business records; Statements of Profit and Loss and of Assets and Liabilities; Business organization; Business practices and methods; the Concern; Analysis and Grouping of Particular Accounts; Handling Accruals; Management problems; Auxiliary Ledgers; The Partnership; Reserve and Valuation Accounts; Handling Business Papers; The Joint Stock Company; Departmental Records; Manufacturing Accounts; The Voucher System; Consignments.
FOURTH YEAR HIGH

RELIGION — Laux, A Course in Religion, Part Four.
Conway, Questions Box.

Doctrinal theme: Brotherhood of man under Fatherhood of God.
The State is not man, not man for the State. Moral theme: Worship; Catholic Action.

Church History and practical discussion of problems that affect the application of love of God and of neighbor to present-day situations.

ENGLISH LITERATURE — De Ferrari, Brentano, Sheekey, English Voices.

While receptivity and enjoyment are primary aims in the study of literature in the first years of high school, criticism of an artistic nature should have a place in the junior and senior years. Besides the recognized masterpieces of the English authors, a number of selections from contemporary authors are included. These selections will satisfy student demand for contemporary material and are in accordance with the sound objective that literature should vitalize and enrich one's life.

Old English, Middle English, Tudor and Elizabethan. Later Renaissance. The Age of Dryden, of Pope, of Johnson. The Romantic Period. Victorian Prose, Victorian Poetry. The Catholic Literary Revival in the Nineteenth Century. The Twentieth Century. The Catholic Revival in the Twentieth Century.

FRENCH LITERATURE — Travis and Travis, Cours Moyen de Français; J. Verno, Le tour du monde en 80 jours, Labiche, Le Baron de Fourchevill.

A general view of the French Literature, the object of which is not so much to recount the biography of authors nor to study the literary works for their own sake but to trace with as much precision as possible the successive phases and the principal directions of the literary production in France. Composition: Literary analysis, essay.

LATIN — Carlisle & Richardson, Fourth Year Latin.

Virgil: AENEID: Books I, II, III (Summary and Selections), IV, V (Summary and Selections), VI, VII-XII (Outline with Selections); ECLOGUE; GEORGIC II.

Ovid: METAMORPHOSES: Atlanta's Race; The Story of King Midas; Daedalus and Icarus; Apollo and Daphne; Pyramus and Thisbe; Defence of Poetry. TRISTIA: The Complaints of Ovid; Ovid's Account of his Own Life. HERMIDES: Penelope to Ulysses. FASTI: The Protection of Rome by Janus; The Story of Arion; Ilia and the Twins; The Festival of Anna Perenna; The Founding of Rome.

CATULLUS: SONGS: The Dedication to Cornelius Nepos Passer Mortuus Est; A Scotch Invitation; Incomparable Lesbia; To Cloe- ro; A Marriage Song; The Desertion of Ariadne; Woman Influen- ding; The English Cookney's Forerunner; A Paradox; All Beauty is Dimmed by Lesbia's Charms; A Taunt to Caesar; Frater Ave Atque Vale.

Martial: Epigrams.

Horace: ODYS: To Mercury; Carpe Diem; An Invitation to Mae- cenas; Integre Vitae; To Venus; The Golden Mean; A Bachelor's Festival; Fons Bandusiae; Exegi Monumentum; CARMEN SAE- GULGRE: Invocation to Apollo and Diana; A prayer to the Twin Deities. SATIRES: The Fable of the City Mouse and the Country Mouse. EPISTLES: Horace's Warning to His Brook; Ars Poetica.

MODERN HISTORY — Hayes, Moon & Wayland, World History.

The purpose of this course is to develop a world viewpoint, to coordinate the history of England and the United States with the rest of the world, and to establish a European background for American history.

The Expansion of Europe; Upheaval in State and Church in Europe; Revolutionary Foundations of Present-day Civilization; Nationalism and Democracy; The White Man's Burden; Modern Civilization on Trial.

SOLID GEOMETRY — Hall & Stevens, Solid Geometry.

Lines and Planes. Dihedral Angles. Solid Angles. Solid Figures. Surfaces and Volumes of Solids. The Cylinder. The Cone. The Sphere.

TRIGONOMETRY — Hall & Knight. Elementary Trigonometry.

The Trigonometric functions of Angles. Radian measure. Identiti- es. Trigonometric equations. Inverse functions. Logarithms and use of tables. Solution of Triangles. Principles of aerial navigation. Principles of spherical trigonometry.

CHEMISTRY — McPherson, Henderson & Fowler, Chemistry at Work. Laboratory manual to accompany textbook.

The purpose of the course in chemistry is to acquaint the student with the accumulated body of fact and theory which constitutes the science of chemistry. Wherever possible, the practical applica- tions of chemistry are made in order that the student may develop an intelligent and constructive attitude toward the science of chemis- try as a disturbing, protective, and constructive agent. The proper- ties of the elements and compounds studied are those which serve for recognition, illustrate a chemical principle, or relate to some important household or industrial use.
States of matter. Types of chemical change. Elements and Compounds. Acids. Fundamental laws. Matter and Energy. The Atomic theory. Theory of Ions. Acids Bases, and Salts. Valence. Halogens. Air. Carbon Monoxide and other fuel gases. Sources of Organic compounds. Fertilizers. Metals in General. Iron. Colloidal state.

Several experiments are performed by the student. Those exercises that interpret and extend the student's experience are preferred to those which merely prove or illustrate factual material of the textbook. The work is so distributed as to give a wide range of observation and practice.

BUSINESS ECONOMICS — Shields and Wilson. Consumer Economic Problems.

The purpose of this course is to help the student become an intelligent consumer by developing a well-rounded viewpoint. The student thus learns to understand the basic economic and social problems. The basic problems that have the most direct bearing upon the consumer are: Money and credit, taxes and tariffs, national and individual wealth and income, economic fluctuations and change, the functions of the marketing system, the use of national resources.

Getting what you want. Consumer protection. Selection and Choice making. Making specific Purchases. Using Banks and Credit. Personal Finance. Insurance Protection. Obtaining a Home. Economic problems of Consumers.

STUDENT ACTIVITIES

Saint Joseph's encourages extra-curricular activities as factors that contribute to the fuller formation of its students. These activities are part of the life of a boarding school and should be part of the life of every student. It is therefore helpful to the student to participate in these activities to the extent that his scholastic standing will allow.

THE CLASS COUNCILS

The Class Councils, composed of the President and other Officers, meet at various intervals during the year. The purpose of this organization is to awaken and sustain a spirit of humanity and loyalty in the school activities; to promote better understanding among students and between the teachers and the students; to encourage student endeavor; to provide for the loyal observance of the school tradition; to achieve wholesome observance of disciplinary regulations, and to assist incoming students to incorporate themselves into the class body.

EXTRA-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES

Four types of extra-curricular activities are recognized and four types of student organizations are represented in the following list.

Spiritual Activities: The Guard of Honor of the Sacred Heart. The Sodality of the Guardian Angels.

Cultural Activities: The Vocational Guidance Club. French and English public speaking clubs. Gregorian Choir. School magazine, Le Sillon, Boy's Band.

Scientific Activities: Nature club (Le cercle des jeunes naturalistes).

Athletic Activities: The student athletic council.

Intramural sports organization.

GRAMMAR SCHOOL DEPARTMENT

The Grammar School at Saint Joseph's is the same as the 7th and 8th grades in the parochial and public schools in the New England States. The successful eighth grade pupil receives a certificate of entrance to high school.
HOLIDAYS

Persons who wish to visit the students should endeavor to do so on the regular holiday afternoons of Sunday, Tuesday and Thursday. The most appropriate time to call the boys on the telephone would be these afternoons, and every evening from six-thirty to seven-fifteen.

Parents are obliged to call their boys home for the Christmas vacation. The School closes during the holiday. Brothers travel home with the students.

REGISTER OF STUDENTS

PAR FOI, JUSTICE

Non loin des bords que baigne le grand fleuve,
En s'égarant de son cours gracieux,
Quels sont ces murs à la carrière neuve,
Dressant si haut leurs flèches vers les cieux?
Oh! c'est bien lui, c'est mon toit, mon collège,
Avec transport toujours je le revois
Se couronnant du bronze qui protège,
Se souvenant du père d'autrefois.

REFRAIN

Amis chantons d'une voix fière,
L'Alma Mater et sa splendeur,
Marchons unis sous sa noble bannière.
Par Foi, Justice, au sentier de l'Honneur.

II

Quand le printemps ranimant la nature
Pare nos bois de ses plus frais atours
L'Alma Mater, sise dans la verdure,
Étale aux yeux sa robe des beaux jours.
Pour la fêter, voyez dans le bocage
Les gais oiseaux chansoner jour et nuit
Comme eux, chantons, puis aimons sans partage
L'Alma Mater, demain comme aujourd'hui.

III

De saint Joseph célèbrons la tendresse,
Le doux regard, le secours paternel.
L'Alma Mater, fidèle à sa promesse,
Lui veut garder un cœur éternel.
Objets chéris de sa bonté touchante,
Nous éprouvons nous aussi ses bienfaits
Que votre voix se recueille et le chante,
Que votre coeur le bénisse à jamais.

Les Clercs de Saint-Viateur

ORIGINE — L'Institut des Clercs de Saint-Viateur a été fondé à Vourles (France), en 1831, par l'abbé Louis Québert, curé. En 1847, un rameau de l'arbre était planté dans le sol fécond du Canada où il pourra croître vigoureusement; plus tard il répandit son ombre bienfaisante sur divers États de la République voisine.

BUT — Sanctification personnelle, enseignement, service des saints autels.

OEUVRES — Écoles primaires et supérieures, collèges commerciaux, collèges classiques, Institution des sourds-muets, écoles d'agriculture, orphelinats, ministère paroissial, maison de retraites fermées, prédication, missions en pays infidèles.

MAISONS DE FORMATION — Juvenats, Noviciats, Scolasticat de théologie, École normale, études universitaires.

Les Soeurs du Sacré-Coeur de Jésus

Les Religieuses du Sacré-Coeur de Jésus ont la direction de la cuisine, de la couture et des réfectoires du Collège Saint-Joseph, à Berthierville.

Les Soeurs du Sacré-Coeur ont des maisons dans les diocèses d'Ottawa, de Montréal, de Mont-Laurier, de Pembroke, de Joliette et de St-Jean de Québec.

La Maison Provinciale, à Ottawa, comprend aussi le Noviciat et le Pensionnat. Dans ce pensionnat, se donnent les cours bilingues de la province d'Ontario. Les élèves y sont préparées aux examens d'entrée de "Lower," "Middle" et "Upper School." Chaque année aussi plusieurs jeunes musiciennes y obtiennent des diplômes de l'Institut Pédagogique de Montréal.

À Saint-Hubert (Chambly), les Soeurs du Sacré-Coeur de Jésus ont leur École Normale et un Pensionnat où se donnent les cours de la province de Québec.

Former les jeunes filles aux usages de la bonne société et aux pratiques de la vie chrétienne demeure le principal souci de ces éducatrices.
SITE

Sur la route nationale qui relie Montréal, Trois-Rivières et Québec, face aux îles du lac St-Pierre, Berthierville déploie sa vie française à travers un treillis de vieux ormes. Ce joli centre régional attire, retient et repose voyageurs et touristes.

La plus importante de ses institutions d'enseignement, le Collège Saint-Joseph occupe une vaste propriété près de l'église et de la place publique, à l'entrée du "chemin du roi". C'est un édifice bâti en 1884. Mais le plan prévoyait deux annexes au corps central. La dernière, de date récente jouit de toutes les améliorations modernes : chapelle, salles de récréation, d'étude, de classe, de douches, dortoirs et studios, autant de pièces spacieuses, claires, ventilées, qui répondent aux moindres exigences de l'hygiène.

Quant à la cour de récréation, les visiteurs l'admirent sans réserve. Un terrain de cinq arpents est aménagé pour les ébats, la gaieté, les agréments de l'esprit; de puissants réflecteurs permettent de l'utiliser aux récréations du soir. Rien n'y manque : pelouses, haie d'arbustes, plates-bandes, promontoires, losanges et filets de balle-au-camp, jeux de paume et de tennis, estrades, abreuvoirs, etc. La vie écolière y jouit d'une saine liberté; tout y favorise la discipline des muscles et l'exercice des vertus sociales.

COURS D'ETUDES

Notre cours d'études comprend deux divisions entièrement distinctes:

1—LE COURS SUPERIEUR BILINGUE suit le programme tracé par le Conseil de l'Instruction Publique pour les cours supérieurs, à base scientifique et littéraire.

Langue française. — Les autorités du Collège Saint-Joseph se font un devoir d'accorder à la langue française la place qui lui revient de droit: la première. Durant les années du cours supérieur, la formation littéraire est l'objet d'une attention spéciale.

Langue anglaise. — Notre programme d'étude assure au jeune homme qui a terminé son cours commercial avec succès une connaissance de la langue anglaise qui lui permet, dès sa sortie du collège de répondre aux exigences des diverses positions qui s'offrent à lui dans le monde des affaires. L'anglais est enseigné par des professeurs franco-américains. La présence d'une centaine d'Américains et d'Anglais lui assure une pratique sérieuse et efficace.

Divers. — La philosophie élémentaire, la comptabilité, la physique, la chimie, la gymnastique, le chant et le solfège sont aussi au programme dans les classes supérieures et complémentaires.

2.—LE COURS ANGLAIS se divise en deux: le cours classique que permet à l'élève diplômé de se diriger vers un collège d'arts libéraux en vue du sacerdoce, de la médecine, du droit, etc. Le cours scientifique permet d'aspirer aux divers "Business Colleges" ou aux études de génie civil.

SYSTEME D'EMULATION

Pour maintenir l'effort de nos élèves dans leur instruction, nous organisons des examens mensuels comptant pour 75%; les récitations et les devoirs journaliers comptent pour 25%.

Un bulletin attestant le progrès des élèves est envoyé aux parents chaque mois.

Seuls, les élèves qui ont conservé 60% sur l'ensemble des notes des bulletins mensuels ont droit de se présenter aux examens du Bureau de l'Instruction publique; les autres passent les examens de la maison.

Si l'élève obtient la note 90% de conduite et 90% de travail, les parents reçoivent une carte d'honneur.

De plus, deux distributions de prix, l'une en février et l'autre en juin, récompensent l'effort des élèves, les prix n'étant attribués que pour les notes de conduite et de travail.

ORIENTATION

Le but de notre Bureau d'Orientation est d'aider nos jeunes, par les méthodes scientifiques modernes, à mieux découvrir leur personnalité et préparer ainsi leur carrière future.

Nous procédons par la méthode des tests standardisés: intelligence générale, aptitudes, manipulation, personnalité, succès dans les matières scolaires; les autobiographies; les questionnaires ou inventaires; les dossiers scolaires; les interviews; l'observation.

Toutes ces connaissances dirigent l'entraînement et les exercices propres à développer les habitudes et les qualités requises pour faire des choix judicieux et des adaptations bien réussies.
