CORRESPONDANCE

Le Directeur contrôle la correspondance. L'introduction
dans le Collège de livres, journaux ou revues ne saurait être
faite sans son autorisation.

CONGES

Il y a trois congés par semaine: dimanche, mardi et jeu-
di, de 12 heures 30 à 4 heures 30. Les grands congés sont dé-
terminés par les autorités du Collège.

PARLOIR, TELEPHONE

Les élèves ne vont pas au parloir ou au téléphone pen-
dant les heures de classe ou d'étude.

LA RENTREE.

L'ouverture des classes a lieu le mercredi qui suit la fête
du travail.

[16]

LA GARDE D'HONNEUR

"Je leur donnerai toutes les grâces nécessaires dans leur
état" — "Les personnes qui propageront cette dévotion auront
leur nom écrit dans mon Coeur, et il n'en sera jamais effacé".
Ces promesses — il y en a douze — faites par Notre-Seigneur
lui-même à sainte Marguerite-Marie explique bien l'accueil
empressé et fervent qu'a reçu cette dévotion que le Procédé-
ce réservait spécialement à notre époque, comme pour la ré-
chauffer au contact de son Coeur brûlant d'Amour. Par l'Arch-
confrérie de la Garde d'Honneur, notre jeunesse veut bénéfi-
cier largement de ces promesses, et la grande faveur que re-
çoit cette Association chez les Clercs de Saint-Viateur ne sur-
prend personne quand on sait que son premier promoteur
dans toute l'Amérique n'est autre que le regrette Père Cy-
rille Beaudry, c.s.v., grand apôtre du Sacré-Coeur et de la
Communion quotidienne.

Au Collège Saint-Joseph, les membres de la Garde d'Hon-
neur se réunissent le vendredi soir pour méditer sur les pro-
messes du Sacré-Coeur, ou pour discuter les différents as-
pects de cette dévotion; ils la font ainsi entrer peu à peu dans
leur vie quotidienne par la pratique de l'heure de garde"
journalière. De plus, ils expriment dans un colloque intime
leurs aspirations, les désirs et les besoins de chacun. C'est ainsi
que ces jeunes, en plus de répondre à un désir pressant de Jé-
sus de le consoler dans son Divin Coeur "blessé" et qui deman-
de "réparation", tendent à s'assurer la réalisation de cette au-
tre promesse: "Je serai leur refuge assuré pendant la vie et
surtout à la mort."

LA CONFRERIE DES SAINTS-ANGES

Avec la dévotion au Sacré-Coeur, par la Garde d'Hon-
neur la dévotion aux Saints-Anges Gardiens est une autre dé-
votion chère aux Clercs de Saint-Viateur qui publient en
France une revue de cette honneur.

S'appuyant sur des textes de l'Ancien et du Nouveau Tes-
tament, de même que sur l'enseignement de l'Eglise, une Con-
frérie a été formée pour développer la dévotion de ces céles-
tes Protecteurs chez les jeunes de qui Notre-Seigneur disait
"que leurs Anges voient sans cesse la face du Père".
En notre Collège, cette Confrérie des Anges Gardiens recrute presque tous les élèves des classes inférieures. Chaque lundi, le samediier réunit à la chapelle les membres pour réciter l'office ou faire quelques considérations sur ces Saints Protecteurs.

Vers la fin de l'année, tous les membres se rendent en pèlerinage au sanctuaire des Saints-Anges, au Juvénat de Berthierville, afin de rendre à leur céleste protecteur un juste tribut d'hommage et de reconnaissance pour les grâces nombreuses qu'ils ont obtenues par leur intercession et les bons offices qu'ils ont remplis auprès d'eux.

L'ACTION CATHOLIQUE

Dans notre Collège, il n'y a pas que des Associations qui tendent à la sanctification personnelle; une impulsion constante est donnée aux élèves pour les amener à penser aux autres, à se dévouer pour le bien commun et pour la bonne santé morale de leur milieu. Déjà l'idée d'apostolat leur est enseignée par le moyen de l'Action Catholique. Dans les directives papales et épiscopales sur ce sujet, on insiste sur l'importance de former l'enfant, l'étudiant, au rôle qu'il devra jouer plus tard comme catholique dans la société.

Aussi avons-nous dans notre maison une section bien vivante de la Jeunesse Etudiante Catholique. Les dirigeants, à leur réunion hebdomadaire, se forcent de se pénétrer du programme qui leur est assigné pour ensuite le faire passer chez les collègues, dans les jeux, la discipline ou l'étude. Leur action est si réelle qu'ils réussissent, à chaque première, à faire participer tous les élèves à une grande campagne d'une semaine, où chacun y met du sien pour faire ressortir, selon ses moyens, les idées principales du programme de l'année qui s'achève. Cette Campagne est encadrée par une démonstration publique dans les rues de la ville; pancartes, chants, discours, chants allégoriques proclament la volonté des jeunes de profiter de leur année de formation pour préparer une société qu'ils auront voulu meilleure.

En plus de procurer des avantages immédiats aux élèves, la Jeunesse Etudiante Catholique contribue à créer une mentalité favorable à l'Action Catholique tant recommandée par les deux derniers Papes, et aussi à lui préparer pour un avenir prochain les hommes d'action qu'elle réclame.

LES ARTS

L'art est la manifestation du beau; c'est aussi l'interprétation de la nature. Où le beau n'est pas en jeu, l'art cesse d'exister; où les proportions, l'harmonie que présente la nature sont méconnues, il n'y a plus d'art. L'altération du sens absolu que doit garder ce mot comporte une idée de supériorité, d'excellence, ce qui habituellement équivaut à une expression de beauté, semblable quand elle revêt une forme. C'est ainsi que la parole, la peinture, le dessin, le chant, la musique sont des arts, et le Collège Saint-Joseph s'y intéresse vivement.

Les Cercles nombreux des littératures française et anglaise, de Jeunes Naturalistes favorisent la maîtrise de soi en public; des cours réguliers de chant de genre développent l'imagination et la précision des élèves; enfin, la musique vocale est représentée par deux chorales, et la musique instrumentale par le piano et la fanfare; plus de cent cinquante élèves bénéficient des leçons de professeurs expérimentés, au service de la jeunesse et de l'art.

LE CERCLE MARSOALAIS

Cette organisation littéraire porte le nom d'un ancien directeur de notre Collège. Se perfectionner dans l'art oratoire et acquérir une meilleure personnalité, voilà le double but de ce cercle. A cette fin, ses membres étudient, lisent et dramatisent des extraits des meilleurs auteurs français et canadiens.

Le Cercle Marsolaïs tient ses séances régulières tous les quinze jours. Chacun débute par la prière et le chant national. Quelques bois discutent des extraits de leur auteur préféré. Suit alors les improvisations. Elles sont de deux genres. Les premières, sans préparation, traitent d'un sujet au choix de la "victime"; les secondes sont préparées. Deux minutes, trois minutes, c'est court! Cependant, que d'impressions, que de craintes accompagnent ces modestes travaux; et aussi, que de maîtrise de soi ils nécessitent. D'autres jours, il y aura des discussions, des lectures, des interviews.

Autant d'occasions pour l'élève d'augmenter sa maîtrise de soi, de soigner sa diction, de se développer une personnalité brillante et d'acquérir peu à peu une saine influence. Seuls les
Le Cercle des Jeunes Naturalistes

Le Cercle des Jeunes Naturalistes se compte au nombre des Cercles en activité dans notre collège. S'il est ainsi considéré des élèves, c'est qu'ils ont compris les connaissances vastes et précieuses qu'il procure à l'éducation.

Son but est de réveiller à tous ceux qui approfondissent les mystères des sciences naturelles, des connaissances particulières des plus attrayantes et des plus réelles. Il agrandit ainsi le vaste champ de nos connaissances, ouvre de nouveaux horizons à nos esprits et nous montre à observer la grandeur et la beauté de la nature déployant sa magnificence devant nos yeux éveillés.

Son programme, presque sans limite, est ainsi des plus vastes. Toutes ses diverses études se portent sur la nature, qu'il cherche à révéler aux jeunes esprits désireux de la connaissance. Un de ses plus grands avantages, est d'instruire en réalité! En effet, que d'heureuses et captivantes excursions nous procure-t-il pas au printemps, à l'automne, presque soudaine des plantes et des insectes? Que d'heures de plaisirs passées dans un sous-bois, à la découverte et à l'étude des nombreux spécimens de notre merveilleuse flore laurentienne! Que de moments délicieux dans la poursuite des petits insectes qui, en un instant, se dérobent à nos yeux, pour réapparaître un instant plus tard...

Il nous invite... Il est attrayant... Faisons nombre à ses côtés!... Profitons de ses nombreux bienfaits.

L'HARMONIE

L'étude de la musique instrumentale est attrayante autant qu'elle est utile. Les exercices de fanfare procurent aux élèves d'intéressantes récréations et constituent les premiers pas vers la culture plus complète de cet art.

LA CHORALE

La musique vocale et le plain chant, enseignés pour fins du culte religieux, préparent des auxiliaires aux chorales de nos églises paroissiales.

[21]
LE SPORT

Tous les élèves doivent faire partie d’une équipe dans un jeu ou l’autre, selon la saison. Il y en a pour tous les goûts et tous les temps. À l’automne, le rugby et la balle au mur sont à l’honneur; les jeux aux récréations du soir, les parties de drapéau organisées entre classes occupent les élèves. L’hiver, le gourou et le patin l’emportent, mais il y a aussi les épreuves en raquettes, en skis, et les jeux intérieurs où les équipes de ping-pong, de badminton, de bilboquet, etc., donnent à la salle une bruyante activité. L’été, la balle au camp devient le sport favori; plusieurs cependant s’adonnent au tennis, à la balle au mur, et aux excursions le long du fleuve ou à travers champs.

Des parties de rugby, de balle au camp, et de gourou sont organisées entre nos équipes et celles d’autres collèges. Divers clubs étrangers se mesurent aux nôtres soit sur la glace, soit sur le losange...

Notre vénéré fondateur n’écrivait-il pas : “Les jeux forment le caractère, habituent au support mutuel, préparent à la vie sociale, font aimer l’école, préviennent le mauvais esprit, dissipent les pensées malsaines”.

Quoique le but principal de tous les efforts soit le plein développement de leurs facultés intellectuelles et morales, néanmoins nos élèves comprennent la parole de Pie XI aux jeunes de Milan : “Pratiquez l’Evangile et pratiquez les sports. Ne négligez ni votre âme ni votre corps.”

LE CORPS DE CADETS

La discipline est la note caractéristique du corps de cadets numéro 239 du Collège Saint-Joseph.

Des cours de gymnastique, de premiers soins aux blessés, de signalement avec drapeaux, lampe et appareil d’émission Morse sont donnés avec succès à un groupe considérable de cadets.

Les trophées décernés à nos cadets prouvent l’excellence du travail qu’ils accomplissent.

[22]

L’AMICALE

Une amicale regroupe en association tous les anciens élèves d’un collège. Elle renoue les liens d’amitié entre camarades disséminés aux quatre coins du pays par les conditions de la vie.

Ces réunions, caractérisées par une franche camaraderie, permettent aux membres d’agrandir le cercle de leurs relations sociales, parmi les nombreux élèves sortis du même collège ayant reçu la même formation, conservant la même traditionnelle affection envers l’Alma Mater.

De cette union intime naissent souvent, en face des déficiences de la vie, des lacunes à corriger et des mouvements à créer ou à maintenir.

Si chaque objet pieux de la chapelle rappelle le souvenir d’un bienfaiteur, d’une bienfaitrice, il faut que nous voitilleurs l’œuvre de nos anciens élèves. La fanfare s’est vu renouveler en une seule fois, tous ses instruments. Les Missions ont eu leur part de généreuses contributions, la cour de récréation s’est enrichie de solides étaudes. Combien de services reçus, de costumes réparés ou confectionnés, et tout cela discrètement offert par des personnes qui ont voulu cacher même leurs noms.

C’est dire que l’œuvre accomplie par l’Amicale du Collège Saint-Joseph fut un tribut d’hommages rendus aux anciens maîtres, par des fils affectueux et reconnaissants. En face de cette longue énumération de bienfaits, les autorités du Collège ont voulu signaler ces gestes honorables des Anciens. Une plaque fixée aux murs de notre chapelle, sous l’autel du Sacré-Coeur, redit leur louange et nous invite tous à adresser au ciel une fervente prière pour tous les Anciens et spécialement pour les membres de l’Amicale.
LE CHANT DU COLLEGE

PAR FOI, JUSTICE

Non loin des bords que baigne le grand fleuve,
En s'égarent de son cours précieux,
Quels sont ces murs à la carrure neuve,
Dressant si haut leur flèche vers les cieux?
Oh! c'est bien lui, c'est mon toit, mon collège,
Avec transport toujours je le revois
Se couronnant du bronze qui protège,
Se souvenant du père d'autrefois.

REFRAIN

Amis chantons d'une voix fière,
L'Alma Mater et sa splendeur,
Marchons unis sous sa noble bannière.
Par Foi, Justice, au sentier de l'Honneur.

II

Quand le printemps ranimant la nature
Pare nos bois de ses plus frais atours
L'Alma Mater, sise dans la verdure,
Etale aux yeux sa robe des beaux jours.
Pour la fêter, voyez dans le bocage
Les gais oiseaux chansoner jour et nuit
Comme eux, chantons, puis aimons sans partage
L'Alma Mater, demain comme aujourd'hui.

III

De saint Joseph célébrons la tendresse,
Le doux regard, le secours paternel.
L'Alma Mater, fidèle à sa promesse,
Lui veut garder un amour éternel.
Objets chéris de sa bonté touchante,
Nous éprouvons nous aussi ses bienfaits
Que votre voix se recueille et le chante,
Que votre cœur le bénisse à jamais.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR,

JOINT EDUCATION - OKA, P.Q.

The Department formerly operated an Indian Day School for Roman Catholic children in the village of Okm, P.Q. When this school was destroyed by fire, these Indian boys and girls were admitted to the two schools maintained by the local School Board for the education of white boys and white girls. An agreement was entered into with the School Board, covering the payment of tuition fees for these children.

When this agreement was reached, in June, 1947, the members of the School Board were considering the erection of a new school and made enquiries as to whether a loan could be advanced by the Department to assist in its construction. Naturally, this was not possible.

Now the Sulpician Fathers have been forced to sell the boys' school through the Provincial Government of the Province of Quebec. It will be necessary for the School Board to buy this building, formerly owned by the Fathers, and to operate it as a school. At the same time they are anxious to renovate the building completely, change the classroom partitions and install proper lighting. It is understood that the cost of the building will be about $25,000.00 and the cost of the repairs about another $20,000.00. Mr. P. Valois, Member of Parliament for Laval-Two Mountains, has made representations on behalf of the School Board and requested that the Department contribute on a per capita basis towards the purchase and restoration of this school. It will of course be necessary to get more adequate details concerning these proposals but it was felt
that the Minister should be made acquainted with these proposals.

These children have been educated at Oka and their progress has been outstanding. In fact there is a marked difference between them and the children who are still being educated at the separate schools (i.e., two United Church day schools still maintained for Protestant children).

I would therefore recommend as follows:

(a) That one of the Education officials of the Branch be despatched to Oka to examine the building, ascertain the relative proportion of Indian and non-Indian children, and the amount estimated as required for the purchase and for renovation of this building.

(b) To discuss the exact details of the School Board's proposal and to obtain from them a fixed sum beyond which the Department cannot be expected to contribute towards this project.

Bernard F. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

Reference: Letter, Nov. 30, 1940.

Further in reply to above letter re Calvin Noganosh, I have made some inquiries about this man with the following results.

His age is now twenty-two and he had formerly attended the St. John's Residential School at Chapleau and passed the entrance examination there in 1934. He is now attending the Shaw Business School in Toronto, taking a general business course. The school principal advises me that his progress has so far been satisfactory and that he is a hard worker and they expect that he will complete the course satisfactorily. The course takes about ten months to complete and the tuition fees are $18.00 per month.

I understand from the school principal that Calvin Noganosh is at present working for a hotel in Toronto and that there is some chance of him being able to use the education he is now receiving along these same lines of employment.

I have known him personally for a couple of years and he is a steady fellow, for an Indian, and a rather likeable chap, whom I think may do something with any education he receives.

Yours truly,

To Whom It May Concern,

Edward Sullivan was a pupil of St. Peter's School during his complete Junior School career. He obtained High School Entrance and then entered our High School. He has completed five Forms without ever missing a year, and holds, now, a complete Junior Matriculation and complete Senior Matriculation certificate.

His success is due to earnest daily hard work and application. He has a splendid character,- a high sense of honour, and a personality which, though manifesting a quiet reserve, is nevertheless much admired. He has always been a favourite among the boys.

Reverend Mother Scholastica,
Superior, St. Vincent's Orphanage,
Peterborough.

Dear Mother,-

I am writing you in the interests of Edward Sullivan who is at present under your guardianship at St. Vincent's Orphanage. This boy has, this year, completed his Senior Matriculation Course after five years' High School work.

There are many opportunities available for me to suggest him as a suitable boy to go on for some higher profession. He is one who will make good use of any opportunity given him. He will, however, need someone to support him, to some extent, during his apprenticeship. It seems too bad that, because he is an Orphanage boy, he cannot take advantage of opportunities offered for higher education.

I trust, dear Mother, that you will give this matter consideration. It might be that the Government which has so generously helped him up to this time, may finance him further.

Thanking you for your co-operation in the past,

I remain,

Yours sincerely

Sister M. Lucretia (Principal)
St. Vincent's Orphanage,
Peterborough, June 16, 1941.

Mr. Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent, Department of Indian Affairs,
Parry Sound.

Dear Mr. Devlin,

I received your letter of June 2, and wish to give you further information regarding Edward Sullivan. I think, too that something definite should be proposed to the Department, and I have one to make.

As I told you, a Druggist in Peterborough, Mr. Stanley Bogue, whose present apprentice is ready for University in October, has asked Eddie to go on for Pharmacy and apprentice with him. He will take him on in July. He will work there for three years with remuneration, little at first, but increasing as he gains experience. This money he could save to put himself through University if the Department of Indian Affairs would still keep him in the Orphanage at the same fee. It is true, that as a grown boy, out at work daily, he will not be of much service to us in the Orphanage, but his fee will pay his board, and we will be glad to help him as much as we can. If the Department sees fit to pay more, every cent of his money, after his expenses are paid, will be saved by him under our supervision. If the Department will not pay more, then for his sake, I would keep him at the same fee.

Perhaps the Department could place him in some good Government position which might have even a better future?

If my first proposal meets with your approval, might it not be well to try it for a year or two, and perhaps something better may present itself in the meantime.

I appreciate your interest, and I shall await further communication from you.

Yours very sincerely,

Sister Scholastica,
(Superior)
Dear Sir:

I have had some correspondence recently with the Mother Superior of the St. Vincent's Orphanage, Peterborough with regard to the further disposition of Edward Sullivan an Indian boy who has been a pupil of the school in Peterborough for a number of years.

This boy has this year completed his education there by taking his senior High School matriculation, and the school officials have such a high opinion of his character and ability that they would like to see him go further. Some tentative arrangements have been made by them for him to study pharmacy by taking an apprenticeship with a druggist in Peterborough, Mr. Stanley Bogue, with a view to him later taking a course in university. His earnings as an apprentice will be small, and, with a view to his saving these towards the cost of a university course, the school officials propose to continue to board him at the orphanage if the Department will keep up the payments of $12.00 monthly which are the board and tuition fees which have been allowed them during his course at the school.

I am enclosing copy of last letter received from the orphanage, also copies of letters of recommendation from the school principal.

Edward Sullivan is an orphan whose parents originally resided on the Moose Point Reserve and were drowned near Midland about twelve years ago. He is now nineteen years old. This appears to be a case in which further education would be of benefit and I am glad to recommend it.

Yours truly,

Samuel Devlin,

I wish to draw attention to the case of Adrienne King, daughter of Solomon King one of the Christian Island families resident in this Agency. Adrienne King has been a patient in the Mountain Sanatorium, Hamilton, for some years and has just recently been discharged from that institution as cured. She was in to see me recently and looked very fit. She did not wish to return to live with her family on the Parry Island Reserve as they have had tubercular history and she has made arrangements to live with some relatives in Toronto.

She is desirous of obtaining some further education and wishes to take a commercial course at the Shaw Schools in Toronto. She advises me that she had endeavoured to keep up with her education while in the sanatorium and had passed through the first grade of high school while there. She is now about 21 years of age and is a bright intelligent girl who would I think justify any expenditures which might be made on her behalf. I am particularly interested in her case since she is one of the few whose lives we have been able to save through sanatorium treatment and I believe that the fact that she has been cured through sanatorium treatment will have a good effect on other Indians infected with tuberculosis who look upon being sent to the sanatorium as a death sentence.

I understand that her relatives in Toronto will take care of her board and lodging and I would be glad to know if the Department will undertake to pay for her tuition in the course which she proposes to take and also possibly make a small cash allowance to take care of clothing and incidentals.

I have just been in communication with the public school inspector for the District who has advised me as to a situation which has arisen with regard to the transport of high school pupils. Arrangements have been made for the transportation of various high school pupils daily from the neighborhood of Pointe au Baril and Shawanaga to the high school in Parry Sound. A contract was made for this purpose with a local man covering a specified number of pupils. Since the contract was made, two more pupils have turned up and as this necessitates the use of a small bus instead of the two cars formerly used by the contractor he cannot take care of these two extra pupils without an additional payment of $3.00 per day.

One of these pupils is an Indian boy, James St. Germaine, whose family belong to the Rama Band but who have been resident close to the Shawanaga Reserve for some years. The other one is an orphan, Phyllis Jones, whose mother formerly belonged to the Cape Croker Band. I told the inspector that we could not accept responsibility in her case and he believes that the Provincial department might be satisfied to pay $1.50 per day on her account if the Indian Affairs Branch will also pay $1.50 per day on account of the St. Germaine boy.

As the arrangements for a bus must be made within the next ten days, I would appreciate your consideration of this matter.

There are two pupils of the Shawanaga Day School who passed the entrance examinations for high school this year. These two pupils are Lorne Pawis, aged 14 and Norma Pawis, aged 15. Requests have been made to me to have them attend high school in Parry Sound. I had been for some time endeavouring to discover what the costs would be, but during the summer holidays, as most of the officials concerned were out of town, I was unable to get anything definite on this until recently. I am now advised by the high school principal that the Provincial Government pays the fees for out-of-town children and that there would therefore be no charge for these two. I am not at all satisfied with this and believe that the Provincial authorities would probably insist on payment by the Department when it was discovered that these were Indian children.

There is also the matter of transportation. A school bus service operates daily between Parry Sound and Pointe au Baril on Highway 69 and passes the Shawanage Reserve en route. I have on my desk an agreement ready for signature by the bus operator in which he agrees to transport these two pupils for the sum of $1.00 per day.

In the case of these children, I am very doubtful if any expenditures on their behalf would be of permanent value. The boy, Lorne Pawis was always a somewhat erratic pupil when attending the Shawanaga Day School and the girl was not much better. I have had on several occasions to pick her up here in Parry Sound and send her back to Shawanaga. I believe that her main interest would be the opportunity to spend time in town.

However, should you think that it would be worthwhile to go
to any trouble to get further education for these two children, if you will send me the regular forms, I will have them completed and returned to you.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.

In September and October, 1947 we had some correspondence as to the situation on the Magnetawan Reserve where there is no school. At that time I had made a tentative arrangement to have three children who were of school age carried by bus to a nearby white school at Britt, Ontario, a distance of between five and six miles from the children's homes. The bus service would then have cost us $3.00 per day for the transportation of these children, but this was considered excessive by the Department. We have now reached the stage where there are a possible nine children on this Reserve who could attend the school at Britt.

I have talked recently to the man who has the contract for the transportation of the Britt children and his charge would still be $3.00 per day, irrespective of the number, which, however, is not to exceed nine. I have not yet contacted the Britt School Board as to what per capita charge they would make on these children but would be pleased to know if you would consider now the payment of the transportation and I will advise you further as to the school costs.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.

If so, you will no doubt advise us later regarding the rate which they will charge. In the event of arrangements being completed, you should make certain that the 9 children attend regularly.

Educational Division.

I am in receipt of an account from the Parry Sound Board of Education covering charges for Larry King, son of Jackson King, No. 110 of the Parry Island Band, who has been attending High School in Parry Sound during the year 1948. I had not been aware until recently that this boy was attending the high school here, until the matter of fees in his case was brought before me. Otherwise, I could have made application in the beginning of the term.

This boy is 17 years of age and had received his primary education at the public school in Depot Harbour on Parry Island. The year 1948 was the first year in high school, he being now in Grade 9 and the high school principal has assured me that he thinks that at the end of the term he will not have any difficulty in being passed to a higher grade. I recognize the fact that no application had been made for payment of these fees in his case but would be obliged if you would give it your consideration, for which I am in the meantime sending forward a voucher.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

Last September my work took me north of Peterborough to paint. While motoring through the country we came upon a settlement of Indians near Burley Falls. They had broken away from the Government Reserve at Curve Lake, to make a living, they claimed for themselves and their families. No doubt this Indian community has already been reported to you, with all the complications connected with it.

The section of Crown land on which these Indians had chosen to "squat" could not be more desolate, barren and rocky, with little or no ground that could be cultivated. There is no school in the district, so the children (twenty-seven of them) are growing up without any education. The majority of them can neither read nor write.

We moved about the settlement, chatting with the different families—not out of curiosity—but with deep interest and concern for the children. We found one boy taking the Department of Education Correspondence Course, this was required of him because his Mother was receiving the Mothers' Allowance. We read the child's papers and as we examined them it became quite clear to us that some older person had been responsible for the major portion of the work. As we met one problem after another we found ourselves subconsciously searching for the solutions. Above all the lethargy that pervaded the place impressed and appalled us. It was a very drab picture but not without hope. In spite of the difficulties in tilling the ground, two families had succeeded in making a flower garden. This encouraged and delighted me. Being a keen gardener myself I appreciated the difficulties they had overcome and it gave me hope of their ability to overcome other things.

As we were leaving the settlement we noticed one family having their evening meal on the verandah of their dilapidated shack, a young girl was cooking something on a fire near-by.
In a flash my mind went back to the many summers I had spent at camp with my Company of Girl Guides and had watched them, times without number cooking their meals just as this girl was doing. Then came the thought, why would not an adaptation of Sir Robert Baden-Powell's plan for Scouts and Guides be the very thing for Indian children? I remembered the keenness with which the Guides responded both in work and play, and as to play, what would be more suitable than the fine Scouting games so well known amongst Scouts and Guides. Then there was the backbone of the whole plan, the aim of developing resourcefulness and the making of good citizens, was not this the aim for Indian Children as well?

Ever since the war broke out, I have been looking for an opportunity to, in some way, be of service to the country. The thought of the possibility of work amongst the Indian women and children so impressed me, that I determined last September to do something about it. Here surely was the thing, not only that I could do, but would like above all else to do.

For years my sister and I had a studio in the Women's Art Association in Toronto. Here we came in contact with Crafts of all kinds, and for many seasons the Secretary of the Association and I acted as judges in the Craft section of the Women's Building at the Canadian National Exhibition. In this way, and with a practical working knowledge of many of the crafts, I have come to know and appreciate the educational value of Craft work. Besides my training in Art and the years of work in the Commercial art world, there were fifteen years experience and periods of training in connection with the Girl Guides Association. My appointment for a period of this time as Camp advisor for the Division of Toronto, gave me ample opportunity to test my own organizing ability. The remembrance of all this, but especially the thought of the children, has emboldened me, a perfect stranger, to write and offer my services to your department in Ottawa, for work amongst the Indians.

Upon my return to Toronto I went to see Mr V.K. Green, the Chief Inspector for the Provincial Department of Education, and told him the story of the Burley Falls Indians. He wrote the Inspector of the Peterborough district, who replied promptly confirming our report, and adding to it, the difficulties he had encountered in trying to meet the situation.

Then I went to see Miss Clark of the Women's Institute Branch. I have made illustrations for her department, from time to time and know and admire the work they are doing in the rural districts. I asked her if she had ever arranged courses for the Indian Mothers and Children. She showed real interest in the matter.
but said the Indians were outside her jurisdiction

On one of my visits to the Indian section at the Royal Ontario Museum, I went to have a chat with Mr. C. T. Currelly. Mr. Currelly has helped me in times past in connection with illustrations for some history books I had to do. I found him very interested in the Indians, of course, and we chatted for sometime on the question of Indians in general. Later I went back to study and make some drawings of the Indian Crafts on display. I mentally compared them with those one sees for sale in the Department Stores, supposedly made by the Indians, and also with a basket some one had recently given me, a basket bought from an Indian women in Muskoka. It seemed to me, if in years gone by Indians could produce such interesting things, surely amongst the Indians of today we could find many who could be inspired to do better things.

The thing I would like very much to do, would be first to visit the Government Reserves and Settlements, for my own information, to have a firsthand knowledge of the resources of each district that might be used in Craft work. To list the resources, limitations and possibilities of each place and plan accordingly. One realizes there are limitations and the necessity of using, not what one can find in the city shops, but in the main what can be found by the Indians themselves in their own community. Then I would like to get to work amongst them.

I have mentioned the subject of the Indians to Mrs. H. B. Warren, President of the Dominion Girl Guides Association, and know, If asked, she would gladly say a word on my behalf. Then too, several friends in Ottawa, who have known me for years, would I know corroborate what I have just written of my training and experience.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Miss Maclaren:

Your letter of the 10th instant, addressed to Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

I note with interest your reference to a settlement of so-called Indians near Burley Falls, Ont. It has occurred to me that this is the group or band of so-called Indians that has been investigated on a number of occasions by officials of this Department. About a year ago Indian Agent Eastwood of Peterboro investigated this Band and reported that of this Band only one - Josh Johnson - was a bona fide Indian, in accordance with the provisions of the Indian Act, and that this particular man was a member of the Mud Lake Indian Band.

It would appear that this group are really half-breed citizens, probably with a certain amount of Indian blood. As half-breeds, however, they are not the responsibility of the Dominion Government. They are citizens in a very absolute sense and as such are the responsibility of the Provincial Government insofar as their education and general welfare is concerned.

You will be interested to learn that about 2 years ago a Handicraft Division was organized in this Department with a senior official in charge. This Handicraft Division has been organized to promote worthwhile handicraft projects on Indian Reserves and to encourage what we term Home Industries on reserves throughout the Dominion. The officials in charge of this Division have already succeeded in organizing a large number of worthwhile industries on a number of reserves in the East and it is our intention to extend this work just as soon as the funds at our disposal will enable us to do so. We have organized and placed on display at the Canadian National Exhibition, Toronto, during the last two years an exhibit of Indian handicraft products. These have included baskets, hand-woven ties, scarfs, rugs, metal work, hand-carved statuettes, leather goods, etc.

It is my intention to pass on your letter to Miss Moodie, the official in charge of this Division. Miss Moodie is at present absent from the office and is not likely to return for a week or 10 days. It has occurred to me that in addition to this you might yourself communicate with Miss Moodie, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, submitting any suggestions you may care to offer.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Miss Edith B. Maclaren,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Thank you for your prompt reply of January 29th to my letter addressed to Mr. Phelan regarding my interest in the work amongst the Indian children.

I appreciated the information in your letter regarding the handcraft department or works in the Indian schools. I had been informed of the intentions of the Branch to revise the curricula of the Indian schools but had not been aware of work being already done by Miss Moodie's division. I regret not having seen the displays you mentioned at the Canadian Nat. Exhibition.

In your letter you say "It has occurred to me that this group or band of so-called Indians (at Burly Falls) that has been investigated on a number of occasions."
When you mentioned a Josh Johnston I knew your surmise was correct. For there was a family of Johnstons. The father was almost blind, the mother was receiving the mother's allowance, the child had had his leg amputated. There was a family - the mother a full-blooded Indian married to a Scotch man by the name of Hogarth. I well remember this family. I was particularly struck with the children. There were quite a tribe of them and most of them had the clear features of their white father, such fine looking little people. This seemed unfortunate as well as remarkable. It was remarkable to me also the intense interest these people stirred within me to the opportunities of work amongst the Indians groups of the country. The heading of your Department describes quite simply this interest, first their welfare, secondly their training.

To return quickly back to the Birch Falls group again. The Indians that made the strongest appeal for help for the children went by the name of Buster Brown. He also had a small
tribe of his own. This family I believe is a pure blood Indian family. His appeal was both interesting and dramatic. He had evidently tried in a weak Indian fashion to solve the school problem of the children. It was he who informed us there were twenty seven children in the community. I cannot vouch for the accuracy of this number only by the number of children we saw, we concluded he could not be far wrong in his count.

I will be very glad indeed to write Miss Moodie as you have suggested. Thanking you again for your letter.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 102-29 of February 8th in regard to the group of people residing at Burleigh Falls, Ont. and in particular "Buster" or Ernest Brown and family, Ernest Brown is the illegitimate son of Mrs. William Smoke, #115 Alnwick Band. His father is supposed to have been a white man from what I can gather. He has been living for at least fifteen years at Burleigh Falls, Ont and has, to my knowledge, never resided on any Indian Reserve in this Agency. He is listed in the Voter's List for Peterborough West, rural polling Division #55, which also includes the name of his wife. In my opinion Brown is definitely not the responsibility of this Department. He is one of a group of persons of some Indian blood, who have no legal status as Indians, who reside in the vicinity of Burleigh Falls. Some of them lease property from the Department of Transportation and others from the Ontario Government. They are wood cutters and general labourers.

On account of them living on Government property the Township of Harvey declines to take any responsibility whatsoever for them and
The Secretary,

this for a number of years has been the reason for numerous investigations, which resulted in nothing being done for these people. They at one time were able to attend school about three and one-half miles distant but apparently were ejected from this school. It would appear to me that the whole set-up is to "oust" these people and have somebody else look after them.

I understand the R.C.M.P. were ordered to evict them about a year ago but there was considerable opposition and public opinion supported these people in remaining and apparently the action was not completed, as they still reside on this property.

In regard to the educational needs of this particular group, I enclose a copy of my letter dated August 5th, 1937. The Provincial Authorities have been well aware of the situation at Burleigh Falls for ten years or more but it would appear that the people in the surrounding district are more interested in getting these people out of the Township than looking after their interests. I endeavoured to get in touch with Mr. Leo Copp, local school inspector, during the week, but was unable to do so until Saturday morning last. He tells me that these people reside on the Forest Reserve, lots 5 and 6, Concession 1, Harvey, which the Department of Education feel should not be set up as a School section at the cost to the Township, as there are no taxes to support a school and until a school section is organized no school can be considered. He has proposed to the Department of Education to carry on correspondence classes for grades 9 and 10 but it is questionable in my mind whether the children would be advanced enough to take this course. Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 103-25 of July 6, 1938, wherein you requested a report concerning eighteen children of the community at Burleigh Falls, in the Township of Harvey, for whom it is claimed the Township of Harvey has been obliged to provide school accommodation and has not received payment from their parents, I submitted an interim report dated July 15th in this connection and on my visit yesterday to this settlement, I wish to confirm that none of these children are Indians within the meaning of the Indian Act.

I requested the names and ages of these children from the County Clerk, who referred me to the Clerk of the Township of Harvey. I wrote the Clerk of the Township of Harvey on receipt of your letter but have not as yet received a reply.

I called at each permanent house at this settlement yesterday and took note of all particulars. I found that the total population numbers fifty-five, thirty-nine of whom were children and, as stated in your letter, there are eighteen children of school age. The parents stated to me that those attending school were ejected two years ago and no children have been attending school since. The nearest school house is four miles north of Burleigh Falls on the Apsley Road. This was the only available school, which they attended. Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 103-25 of August 26th, stating that Norman Marsden had written a letter requesting assistance for his boy, Robert Marsden, to complete his high school course, I wish to refer you to your letter 103-25 of August 14th, wherein the usual grant of $65.00 was allowed to enable this boy to continue at high school for another year. Apparently this is unsatisfactory to Norman Marsden. From what he tells me the bus from Roseneath to Campbellford has discontinued its service and Norman Marsden is unable to make arrangements to have the boy live at home and go to Campbellford each day, as he has in the past. What he proposes to do is to have the boy go to his son's home in Toronto and have the boy attend school from there. He wishes to secure sufficient of a tuition grant to board the boy at his son's home in Toronto at $5.00 a week. This would mean approximately forty weeks at $5.00 a week and a total cost of approximately $200.00, which is a considerable amount in comparison with what the previous assistance has been.

I also was under a misunderstanding from Norman Marsden in regard to the progress of the boy and have recently learned that he is in third form, of the Collegiate, and not in the Matriculation form, as previously advised. This would mean two more years of schooling.
In view of the fact that an application of Mrs. Ross Beaver, of the same Reserve, for a tuition grant to enable her daughter, Vivian, to attend High School, has been refused, on account of no allowance for new grants for 1941-42, I cannot very well recommend the increased grant for Norman Marsden's boy.

I think that Norman Marsden can arrange some method of having his boy continue at Campbellford and if not, his other son in Toronto could bear part of the cost, if arrangements were made to send the boy to Toronto. I think if the family is sufficiently anxious to have the boy continue, that the present grant could be made to do.

I explained this matter in full to Norman Marsden before he wrote his letter to the Department and endeavoured to show him that I could not fairly recommend an increase when others were refused assistance on account of economy.

Your obedient servant,

Indian agent

Coldsprings, September 25th.

To W.A. Fraser, Esq., M.P.

I am writing you regarding a matter that seems to me to be very unfair.

These are the facts. A daily bus from Roseneath transports 29 pupils Cobourg Collegiate, 4 of them are Indian from Alderville Reserve. Twenty-five of these from Roseneath taken practically free, due to grants. The other Indian children have to pay $10.00 per month each for this accommodation. Their parents are poor and the least able to pay but the children are clever and ambitious. One girl, Norma Beaver, who gets honours in her course each year, has one brother serving in Italy (wounded recently), another serving in France, and a third preparing to go overseas. Surely a family such as this deserves the very best advantages Canadian Schools can give without the added burden of transportation.

You will know who should deal with this gross injustice and it is my hope that you will take the matter up at once. A remedy should be found immediately because school is now open and they are in attendance.

Their parents are appealing to me for corrections of this condition and I promised to consult you as our representative.

I am in charge of the Alderville Mission and have served among them for nearly eight years.

Yours sincerely,

sgd) H. Lander

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

With reference to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of October 4, regarding certain children from the Alnwick Reserve who are attending Cobourg High School, Inspector Arneil investigated this matter when he was on the Alnwick Reserve on October 14. There are five children from the Alnwick Reserve who wish to attend Cobourg Collegiate:

1. Lois Bigwin - 12 years of age, passed the entrance this year.

2. Nona Simpson - 13 years of age, passed the entrance this year.

3. Max Beaver - 13 years of age, passed the entrance this year.

4. Alton Bigwin - This boy is not quite 17 years of age. He is in fourth year high school work.

5. Norma Beaver - Nearly 17 years of age. She is taking third year high school work, with special reference to a stenographic course.

Inspector Arneil considers that all the above-mentioned children should be encouraged to attend high school. The fee will be $10 a month for transportation, plus the tuition fees at the Cobourg Collegiate, which will be at the rate of approximately 53¢ a day. I should appreciate having your authority to notify the Indian Agent that we will allow the amounts mentioned above.

George Paudash, Band #52, Rice Lake band has a son and a daughter, June Paudash, 18 years of age and Lloyd Neil Paudash, 16 years of age, that he would like to have attend school in Peterborough but finds the cost is beyond his means. I have discussed the matter with him as I am anxious to have these two children continue their education and he states that some assistance to cover the cost of board and transportation would make it possible for him to have them continue.

Lloyd Paudash would like to attend the vocational Course of the Peterborough Collegiate and vocational School at Peterborough. He is a bright intelligent boy who has just passed his entrance this year. He is bright and intelligent and should do well especially on this course as he has a natural aptitude towards mechanics. June Paudash has completed her fourth year at Peterborough High School and would like to attend Peterborough business college in order to take a commercial course.

I would suggest that a grant of $100.00 for each would materially assist him in paying the costs of transportation and board for the year.

George Paudash has recently received his discharge from the Veteran's Guard and he lost a son Herman, who was a Pilot Sergeant in the R.C.A.F. He was reported missing in a flight over Germany in 1943 and after a considerable length of time was officially reported as presumed dead. Herman received a tuition grant to send him to the Peterborough Collegiate and Vocational School and did very well in his studies and showed exceptional promise but the war interrupted the completion of his studies. I recommend that assistance be granted to both these children.

Each time I have come to the conclusion that I would like to be a doctor. I well understand that high standing is required in Algebra, Geometry, Physics and Chemistry, in fact, at least second class honours before I could enter medical studies. Last year I got six subjects but I went back to school this year to raise my standing in the previously mentioned subjects. This year I work more diligently and my results are better. We have your letter of the 24th inst., enclosing letter from Alton Bigwin requesting tuition grant for the next academic year in order to enable him to take a medical course at either Toronto or Queens University.

We have read Bigwin's letter and also the letter from the principal of the Cobourg Collegiate. Provided Bigwin is successful in the examinations at the end of the current academic year we are prepared to favourably consider granting him assistance.

Bigwin's letter is slightly indefinite as you will note from the following sentence. "Should I not attain good marks in all subjects I would pursue studies in some other course". Bigwin should understand that he must make a definite decision what course he intends to follow before he enters university. If he is not successful in that course, the Department will not be able to grant him any further assistance. In other words, we cannot promise to provide a tuition grant if he switches from one course to another.

Enclosed is one of our regular application forms for a tuition grant. This should be completed after Easter at which time you can obtain from the principal of the Cobourg Collegiate, the marks obtained by Bigwin at the Easter examinations.
You will notice on the reverse side of the application form that the medical certificate should be completed by a doctor. Before allowing a tuition grant, we wish to be assured that the applicant is reasonably healthy and we would like him to be physically able to continue the course he begins.

In reply to file 103-25(WT1) dated the 27th of February, I submit herewith an application for tuition grant on behalf of Elmer Alton Bigwin, son of James Bigwin Jr., #213 Alnwick Band. Attached is a completed medical certificate as required.

I have interviewed Elmer Bigwin and he is firm in his mind as to his intentions of taking up medicine if financial assistance is forthcoming. He has submitted to me a summary of student's expenses based on thirty weeks in the first school year. He states that the academic fees increase in the second and third years. Based on the first year's expenses, he considers the following would be his minimum requirements:

| Item                          | Cost   |
|-------------------------------|--------|
| Board and Lodging (30 weeks @ $15 per week) | $450.00 |
| First year academic fee        | $200.00 |
| Registration fee per year      | $25.00  |
| Books                         | $40.00  |
| Athletic Association          | $10.00  |
| Instruments                   | $30.00  |
| Students Health insurance     | $10.00  |
| Incidentals (class fees etc.) | $40.00  |
| Microscope (if it has to be purchased or $25 per year rental) | $150.00 |
| Laundry pressing etc.          | $50.00  |

Microscopes can be rented if registered early enough at $15 per year plus $10 per year in the case of damage. This would amount to $150 at the end of six years.

A student would have a very short earning period during the summer holidays but he states that he could possibly earn sufficient to purchase his clothes and other requirements above those listed.
From the $1005 estimated, his father states that he can provide $200.

I realize this is a tuition grant of very large proportions over the six or seven years and it is doubtful whether the boy's father could assist his son in a greater amount than $300 or $400. I would like to add that his father may be able to increase his assistance as he is one of the most progressive farmers on the Alnwick Indian reserve since he started six or seven years ago. He has at the present time fifteen cows and three young cattle, has purchased a Fordson tractor on his own without assistance and is hoping to put in a larger crop this year and proposes to rent some additional property from his neighbours who are not using their land.

Mr. V.M. Eastwood, Indian Agent,
385 Water St., Peterborough, Ontario.

We have your letter of May 5th giving detailed information regarding the request of James Bigwin, Jr., for assistance to enable him to take a medical course. In one portion of your letter you state that the father can provide $200, and later on you mention the amounts of $300 and $400. I presume you mean that we can depend on the father for $200 a year. Possibly he might be able to provide either of the higher sums. Please confirm this matter.

As the university term is only thirty weeks, it means that there are approximately twenty-two weeks on which James Bigwin Jr., might earn money to help himself, if he can secure any kind of a position. As you are aware, many white boys in the same position as Bigwin earn during the holiday period a considerable portion of the funds required for their university course.

As you state in your letter, this request is for a tuition grant much larger than usually allowed. We must take into consideration also, the fact that if he continues to be successful in the course, we will have to continue assistance for six or seven years.

The matter is sufficiently important for us to request that Bigwin pay a visit to the Department. At that time we will arrange to have him meet Dr. Moore, the head of the Medical Services, and other departmental officials.
We believe we are justified in making this request as we would like to have a personal interview with him.

In the event of his accepting this suggestion, you should notify us a week or ten days before he comes so that we may make certain the officials whom we wish him to meet will be in Ottawa.

Manual Training Mud Lake Indian Day School and Alnwick Indian Day School.

Manual Training is now available to these two schools and is being taught at the Rice Lake Combined School which is a school administered by the Township of Otonabee and to which school board an annual grant is made for the instruction of Indian children of the Rice Lake Band.

I have been in touch with Mr. J.L. McColl of 635 Oxford Street, Peterborough, who is in charge of manual training for the Department of Education for Ontario for this area. His training comes under the supervision of the local inspector for this Department. No doubt the Department is familiar with the set up of this type of training but to cover it fully in this letter Mr. McColl tells me that an annual course is put on in these schools and that the manual training teacher visits the school one day or each week and lays out work to be completed at his next call the following week. 60% of the instruction is in woodworking; 20% of the time is taken up in instruction of sheet metal work, soldering, tinsmithing and rope work; the remaining 20% is of miscellaneous work covering work in leather, painting, glazing glass and other appropriate work that can be utilized by Indians on the Reserve.

The Instructor will be in charge of a small kit of woodworking tools which he will leave at the school. They can purchase this kit at a 25% reduction and a nucleus of tools would cost approximately $30. A work bench and some tools have been purchased for the Mud Lake Indian Day School and these tools with the kit available from the manual training teacher would appear to be all that would be required in tools for the moment.

The cost per school for tools is set at 5¢ per pupil per month. The allowance for teacher and supplies is $190 per teaching year per school.

The estimated cost for Alnwick Indian Day School where there would be seven boys over nine years of age who would take training would be $190 + $3.50 making a total of $193.50.
The estimated cost for Mud Lake Indian Day School where there are approximately 24 boys of age to take manual training would be $190 + $2.00 making a total of $202.00.

Mr. McColl states that while it is to an advantage to have a separate room for manual training, the work is done in most rural schools right in the classroom. A separate room is available in the Mission House now temporarily used as a school house for the Alnwick Band. At Mud Lake there is a large basement room originally intended for this work.

May favourable consideration be given to installing manual training in these two schools.

V. M. EASTWOOD,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have registered at the University of Toronto. For nearly five weeks I have attended the lectures in the Pass Arts Course at University College.

Yesterday I had a long, informal chat with Mr. G. Beatty, Dean of the faculty of Arts. He was very helpful in that he gave me every encouragement to my ambitions. Dr. Beatty stated that due to my Indian stock the University would certainly want to encourage such a move and would thus endeavour to arrange my change in course from Pass Arts to Pre-Medical next year provided that I do sufficiently well this year. He suggested that I write of my intentions to Dean MacFarlane of the faculty of Medicine. Another suggestion was that I tell you that I am taking these subjects: Maths A, Physics, Chemistry, English la-b, and philosophy B. "This course", he stated, "corresponds very much to that of the first pre-medical year," so that there would be no hindrance in my switching next year. Lastly, Dr. Beatty is writing a letter to the Department stating the required particulars.

During the summer, though I was very careful of my expenditures, I was only able to make about $220. I only bought a new suit and some shirts out of this amount. When I came to school, I paid the first instalment of fees which amounted to one hundred and fifty-six dollars. Then my gym equipment and locker cost ten dollars. My books cost just a shade under fifty-dollars. After spending this amount I hadn't much left. My Dad, though he hasn't a high income, helps to pay my board which is fifteen dollars a week. Now there is my board for the year, my second payment of fees etc. to pay. If I am to get good marks in order to enter Pre-med next year, I think it wise to spend much time in study and not to work. This means that money for my board must come from elsewhere so I am urgently and hopefully asking that the Department grant me as much assistance as possible. As ironically stated in the first line of this page I am in debt. Reassuring you that I will put forth the utmost effort in studying I hope I am able to get as much help as was suggested by Col. Weary last May.

Yours truly,

"Alton Bigwin"

Re: Mr. Alton Rigwin, I Pass.

I understand from young Mr. Rigwin that in order for you to decide whether to recommend him for further assistance or not, you would need to know how he is doing in his studies.

I have made inquiries and find that in I Pass he is taking the following subjects:

Physics la 4 hrs. a week,
Chemistry 2 3 hrs. a week,
Mathematics la, lb 3 hrs. a week,
Philosophy lb 2 hrs. a week,
English la, lb 3 hrs. a week.

He has had term examinations to date, and the results seem to indicate that he is at least an average student - perhaps a little better than that in such subjects as the first three above. Re: Tuition Grant to Alton Bigwin #213 Alnwick Band.

With reference to file 103-25(WT1) dated October 29, 1947 wherein I was advised that Alton Bigwin had been allowed a tuition grant of $400.00 for the current academic year, $350.00 of this grant was received at this office and now has been expended to date with the exception of a balance of $19.00.

Credit vouchers have been forwarded regularly on the receipt of accounts.

I am submitting a letter from the Dean of the Faculty of Arts, Toronto University, setting out Alton Bigwin's standing at the Christmas examination results. I have retained a copy of this letter.

Assuming the current year would be completed by May 15th there will be twelve weeks at $15.00 a week or $180.00 to be paid out in board. The funds on hand, inclusive of the $50.00 additional authorized amounts to $69.00 which will be short $111.00. It would appear that in order to complete his year, he will require an additional amount of $111.00.

In Alton's letter to me he suggested that if he were granted $75.00 more, he would endeavour to borrow the rest.

In recommending that he be given an additional grant of his requirements of $111.00 I would do so on the understanding that any further assistance would be on at least a 50/50 basis. He would have the whole summer to earn funds for his expenses in his second year and his father has promised to assist him to a greater extent than he has this year. I believe the father will be financially able to do so as he has an excellent herd of 25 cattle and is doing a good job of cultivating his land. His father has completed payment for some improvements to his house, has purchased some additional farm machinery and expects to be able to assist Alton to a greater degree.

V. M. Eastwood, Superintendent,
Hicé and Mud Lakes Agency.

You should, therefore, apply for same about April 1st.

Mr. Bigwin should understand that further assistance should be on a 50-50 basis. He should be able to earn considerable funds during the coming summer and as his father is in comfortable circumstances, he should be in a position to assist his son.

Bernard F. Neary

Re: Tuition Grants--Academic Year

The following students from the Alnwick Band have expressed their desire to attend the Cobourg High School. For their assistance the same grant as allowed last year is requested, that is $120.00 for the transportation plus tuition.

1. Elgie Mersden: completed 1st year having secured second class honours.
2. Katherine Gray: recommended by her teacher John Loukes to attend 1st year collegiate.
3. Rodger Crowe: recommended by his teacher John Loukes.
4. Mona Simpson: has completed her 3rd year having past successfully.
5. Lillian Bigwin: recommended by John Loukes.

The following of the Mud Lake Band:

Eric McCue: has completed his 1st year and would like to continue. I enclose his report received from the Principal, C. S. Browne. He was in receipt of a $200.00 grant for his first year. I would like to have this renewed.

Hannah Muskratt: recommended by Miss Bertha Long. She is desirous of attending the Peterborough Business College. In reply to file 42025-3(E) of August 22nd 1949 requesting a report on letter from Mrs. Robert Cowie, Band No.49 Rice Lake concerning renewal of tuition grants for 1949-50 for her two children, Lucille age 14 and Boyd age 17, who attended Peterborough Collegiate and Vocational School 1948-49 and who both failed. In my letter of 23rd of August I applied for a tuition grant for assistance to Lucille to attend Peterborough Business College. With this request I provided her report and letters of recommendation from her former teacher. Mrs. Cowie's letter and newspaper clipping are attached.

Dear Sirs:

In this village of Hiawatha there are five students who attended high school in Peterborough; three have gone two years and two have had their first year.

CHARGE MARKING OF EXAMS
'DISHONEST' AT PETERBORO

Special to The Star
Peterboro, July 30—Charges that the whole system of setting and marking examinations in the collegiate and vocational school here was "dishonest and absolutely unfair to the students" were made today by Dr. H. G. Carleton, chairman of the supervisory committee of the board. A full investigation has been ordered by the superintendent of education.

Dr. Eldon P. Ray, one of the collegiate teacher's, published a newspaper advertisement in which he said "tests were fair" and that "placing the blame for poor results on the staff simply provided a scapegoat for parents and students who have shirked their responsibility."

Reports received by the board of education showed only 53 of the 115 grade 11 students passed in all subjects. Thirty-two failed and 30 others must write supplemental examinations before the fall term.

"My guidebook is the fact that our students are not passing and, in fact, results have not been as good as in other schools during the past few years," said Dr. Carleton. "The board is unanimously behind my charges; the system is dishonest. Teachers can fix marks any way they wish and are not averse to favoritism."

Don't Consider Students
"Apparently the members of the board were satisfied to attribute the poor results to teaching, the examinations and the marking without considering another force in the school—namely, the students," Dr. Ray said in his advertisement. "A fair report on the examination results would have given some consideration to the student desire to learn, student participation in school activities and demands on student time outside the school.

"The chairman of the supervisory committee evidently has a very unfavorable opinion about the integrity and ability of the teachers of the school when he charged them with 'dishonesty' and being 'absolutely unfair' in the conduct of examinations," the advertisement said.

"Such statements are absolutely unfair because the person who makes them can do so under cover of the board, without fear of consequences, knowing he cannot be compelled either to prove his allegations or to retract them.

"Go To Pasture?"
"Moreover, Dr. Carleton has some views about the poor mental health of teachers, and apparently is in favor of a year's leave of absence. But did the good doctor not get the prescriptions for beast and man confused when he suggested that teachers "go to pasture for a year and maybe they could come back?"

"Dr. Carleton's description of the examination results as 'the worst I have ever seen in a collegiate' is emphatic to say the least," the paid advertisement continued. "Is this a statement of fact based on the study of examination results at P.C. V.S. in comparison with the results of the other schools over a period of years, or a personal and perhaps biased opinion arising from the results of this year?"

The total board is $17.00 a month. You will notice that I have obtained from the Fathers, a copious reduction of $7.00 a month, leaving the board $10.00.

To my opinion, the members of the Honourable Staff of Indian Affairs would congratulate themselves in years to come, of having protected the said child.

Dear Sister:

Re: Alphonse Metalic

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 4th instant, written on behalf of the above-noted Indian pupil. In this connection I am sending forward a letter addressed by me a few days ago to Mr. Arsenault. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory. We are, at the present time, acting under definite instructions not to encourage Indian boys to take up academic or classical courses. The officials here feel that such boys should be encouraged to take up vocational or semi-vocational courses at recognized technical schools. Apart from this policy, however, it is noted that a tuition grant has already been granted to the brother of this boy and it would be very unusual indeed to assist two boys in the one family. I should add also that it has never been our policy at any time to assist pupils to take up professional courses such as Medicine, Law, Theology, etc. It would be exceedingly difficult to justify the use of public funds for such advanced courses.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Cher monsieur:

Nous désirons vous informer qu'une demande nous a été soumise pour l'acceptation, sous la loi de l'Assistance publique, des frais d'entretien du susnommé à l'Ecole Victor Doré.

Il s'agit d'un dépendant d'Indien dont le père, séparé de son épouse, demeure présentement dans la réserve de Restigouche, P.Q., et la mère habite Montréal depuis quelques années.

Comme toutes demandes d'assistance, pour ces fils naturels du pays, doivent être assumées par le Gouvernement fédéral, il nous est impossible, à moins d'une autorisation de votre part, d'accorder l'aide demandée.

Par conséquent, auriez-vous l'obligeance, par le retour du courrier, de nous faire connaître votre manière de traiter ces cas, c'est-à-dire si vous pourvoyez vous-même à un tel placement ou bien si vous acceptez l'intermédiaire de services provinciaux ou municipaux.

Dans ce dernier cas, avec votre autorisation et promesse de remboursement, nous pourrions, si la chose peut convenir, nous occuper de régler le cas, en effectuant le placement de l'enfant au coût de l'assistance publique, soit $0.66 par jour (journées scolaires) sans compter les frais de l'Institution.

Nous espérons recevoir de vos nouvelles sous peu et vous prions de croire en notre plus entière collaboration.

Votre bien dévoué,

Conrad Saint-Amant

We wish to inform you that an application has been submitted to us for the acceptance, under the Public Charities Act, of the costs of maintenance of the above-named at the Victor Doré School.

This is a question of a dependent of an Indian whose father, separated from his wife, is at present living on the Reserve at Restigouche, P.Q., and whose mother has been living in Montreal for several years.

As all requests for assistance for these indigenous sons of Canada must be assumed by the Federal Government, it is impossible for us, without authorization on your part, to grant the help asked for.

Consequently, would be kind enough to inform us by return of mail as to your manner of treating these cases, i.e., do you see to them yourself or do you avail yourself of provincial or municipal services.

Dear Sir:

I wish to give you the following instructions concerning the course the Indian girls are taking at Ponemah Vocational Training School.

The principal informs me that the regular course giving right to a diploma is of three years and requires besides practice much study on account of which our Indian girls are unable to follow.

The secondary course is one of house-hold science and lasts two years. It aims at preparing girls to face their duties as mother and wife and teaches them practically all domestic sciences. A third year is recommended to specialize in one subject. This course gives a certificate. This is the course our
Indian girls are following.

On leaving Pinawa Vocational Training School the Indian girls might be able to give demonstrations to young ladies and even married women but one of the teachers would necessarily have to organize a club and act as supervisor.

Dear Sir,

The principal of the Restigouche Day School has always wished to have a barber course made by one of our ancient Indian school boys as there is no barber shop on this reserve. I have already submitted my opinion on this subject to our benevolent Ottawa Inspectors, particularly Mr. A.J. Doucet and they have approved my desire but I have always been prevented to do so due to lack of a proper apprentice shop.

This week I have discovered a bilingual barber academy in Moncton, N.B., which gives complete courses on the said profession. Dear Sir:

Answering your letter of the 6th, we must say we are at a loss to know how these accounts should be made. This is the first time we have had pupils having a tuition grant from the Department of Indian Affairs Branch. They were admitted at our institution through correspondence.

We received from the Department the following amounts in September:

Eleanor Gedeon $35.54
Ruth Bernard $40.00

This amount included extras. Since the Department has already given the above part payments in September, we cannot submit accounts to the amount of $30.00 for the Months of October, November and December, as this will not correspond to the allowance given for the grant, that is $120.00 for this school term, as per a copy of a letter we have here from the Superintendent of Education, Bernard F. Re: Application for Tuition Grant  
Therese Vicaire, Restigouche, Bon. Que.

With reference to the above noted pupil I wish to submit the following report:

Recently, the Principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School visited this office. Her main reason for doing so was to enquire if an application had been submitted for authority to send the above mentioned girl to a vocational school.

Upon interviewing the Principal the latter stated that a request had been made to Mr. E. Arsenault, Indian Agent at the time. I have checked our files and as much as I can find, I gather no application was ever made in this case.

The Principal also stated that Miss T. Vicaire attended the Holy Rosary Vocational School at Rimouski, P.Q. approximately two years and was kept home during the academic year of 1947-1948 and as much as we can ascertain, her mother was the cause of it due to her health condition.

Since this girl was doing very good at school and anxious to return for one more year to complete her course, the Principal took for granted that the application would be approved and made the necessary arrangements with the Principal of the School at Rimouski for her admission.
The result is now that Miss Therese Vicaire has been attending the Rimouski School since the opening in September at a cost of $35.00 per Month.

In view of the circumstances, I have made no promise to the Principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School that this expenditure would be paid by the Department, however, due to the fact that this girl has already spent two years at this school and that another year would permit her to complete her course, I would strongly recommend that a grant of $350.00 covering the whole year of schooling be approved.

I have interviewed Miss Vicaire today, who is back on the Reserve for the Holidays and stated that She was doing well and was anxious to return after the holidays.

I would therefore appreciate an early reply concerning this matter.

With reference to the above noted child I wish to inform the Dept. that He has completed its 8th. grade at the Restigouche Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter 42027-3 (E.I.) of Oct. 18 re. Jay Edgar attending Port Perry high school. Six Nations Council Resolution No.13, Sept.6/45.

The Council by the above resolution approved of paying the tuition fees for eight children in order they may continue their education at High School. The first three pupils named were attending High School last year but owing to the fact they were unable to win promotion, are not eligible for Departmental grants this year, consequently their parents who wish them to continue, appealed to the Council and they saw fit to consent to paying the fees.

The remaining pupils are all successful Entrance pupils but whose standing after the examinations was not sufficiently high in the opinion of the Inspector to warrant him recommending them for Departmental grants. The Department will appreciate that examination marks are not always a true criterion of the ability of pupils, so this office is of the opinion that the pupils concerned should have the benefit of the doubt and be given an opportunity to continue their education under the assistance given them by the Council.

Upon approval being received from the Department this office will make the usual arrangements with the High Schools concerned and have the tuition fee invoices separated from those actually paid by the Department.

"Six Nations Council Resolution No. 13, Sept. 6/45.

The Council by the above resolution approved of paying the tuition fees for eight children in order they may continue their education at High School. The first three pupils named were attending High School last year but owing to the fact they were unable to win promotion, are not eligible for Departmental grants this year, consequently their parents who wish them to continue, appealed to the Council and they saw fit to consent to paying the fees.

The remaining pupils are all successful Entrance pupils but whose standing after the examinations was not sufficiently high in the opinion of the Inspector to warrant him recommending them for Departmental grants. I have received a request for a tuition grant for Ruth Fraser, who is stated to be a daughter of Joseph Fraser, of Ohweken.
