Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Re: Tuition Grants for Indian Children Attending High Schools, and Collegiate Institutes.

In connection with the above, you are aware that for some years past, it has been our policy to authorize the attendance of certain Indian children of the Six Nations Reserve at Brantford Collegiate Institute, and Hagersville High School. In each case, we have been responsible for the tuition fee, and have also allowed $100.00 to the parents for extra expenses, that they were obliged to provide for their children.

When I was in Brantford last week, I discussed the above situation with the Indian Superintendent, Colonel Randle, and the Public School Inspector, Mr. Webster, who inspects the Indian Day Schools, and Six Nations and New Credit Reserves.

During the course of our conversation, I was informed that in many cases the parents of children have to provide a considerable amount more than we allow. This is caused by purchasing extra clothing, and in some cases, providing for the maintenance of children in Brantford. In other cases, especially girls, they live in a white home, and do housework for their maintenance, but attend school during the day. This practice has not always worked out very satisfactorily, as some employers oblige the girls to work until a very late hour in the evening. In other cases, when the girls are allowed out to attend a show etc., it has been found difficult to have them return home at a reasonable hour.

Mr. Webster felt that it would be advisable for us to consider the possibility of transporting the children to and from the Reserve each day. Judging from his experience, in certain communities outside of Brantford, he felt that we can secure transportation for considerably less than the amount of $100.00 that we now allow for each pupil.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of July 16 in which you make inquiry concerning Miss Ruth Fraser's High School Certificate. I recently had occasion to review some of Miss Fraser's school records on some other business and noted that her High School Entrance Certificate bears the date of July 5, 1943 and was properly signed. I do not know the name of the school she was attending at that time but I could get it by corresponding with her parents and send it to you later if you so desire.

Miss Fraser spent three years at Ontario Bible School and we found her to be a fine quiet girl of good moral standing. She did not rank high in scholastic standing but was quite diligent and faithful in her work. She was out of school at times for farm service at home during the critical years of the war and these absences no doubt had some bearing on her grades.

The establishment of bus routes to convey High School pupils to their respective schools, raises one or two problems for clarification.

First, the pupils who failed last year to secure promotion. As you know, in past years when we were giving grants, if a pupil failed to gain promotion we discontinued their grant and the pupil normally left school, as the parents could not afford to pay the tuition fees. There were a few exceptions to this where either the parents or the Council made the necessary payment.

Now with the establishment of bus routes and no grants, is the Department willing to permit those who failed last year, to continue, and also pay their tuition fees?

Secondly, we have three pupils in the south part of the Reserve who have always gone to Waterford High School and now owing to road conditions and their extreme isolation the bus routes we are establishing could not reach them without wasting much time and road miles. May they be permitted to continue going to Waterford and receive the usual $100.00 grant?

Also, we have two pupils in the Upper School at Brantford Collegiate, whom it would be unfair to transfer at such a late date to Hagersville High School. May they be permitted to finish their education at Brantford Collegiate, and receive the usual grant?

There is also one boy, crippled through Polio', - who is rated as having the highest intelligence of all last year's Grade 8 pupils, who wishes to go to boarding school, - the Fort Erie Bible School. This is really the best place for this disabled boy, and it is recommended we allow him a $100.00 grant, particularly as his family are in very poor circumstances.

Then, Jessie King, who has had two successful years at Hagersville High School, would like to go on to Business College in Hamilton, and if possible receive a grant.

Re: Transportation, Six Nations Superintendent.

With reference to your letter of June 4th concerning the provision of School Bus facilities for High School pupils and Vocational Training classes in this Superintendentcy, we are now enclosing the tenders of two persons concerned.

Both tenders are at the rate of .35¢ per mile and that of Mr. Schurr covers 352 miles per week, and that of Mr. Styres 260 miles per week.

As it has been found after all children have been spotted on the map of the Reserve, that the bulk are centered around the middle and eastern portions of the Reserves, - to save operating over a large number of unnecessary miles we are diverting all pupils to Caledonia and Hagersville High Schools, and cutting out Brantford.

As you may remember, both Hagersville and Caledonia are adjacent to the two Reserves, while the Western boundaries of the Reserve at the nearest point is six miles from Brantford. Also in the event of heavy snow it would not take much effort to keep entry into Hagersville and Caledonia open, but we might have difficulty in getting the County or Brantford Township to keep essential roads open at the necessary time.

Consequently we propose to have one bus taking the High School pupils, approximately 30 pupils, to Hagersville, - a return run of 58 miles daily; - and the other bus to Caledonia with approximately 30 pupils, a return run of 40 miles daily.

In addition we shall have five local Vocational Training routes. Last year we only had three, but with the addition of the girls and also the fact that there is a much larger percentage of children in Grades 7 and 8 this year, - we have to split the groups in five, - otherwise the classes would be too large for the limited capacity of the Manual Training and Home Economics school-rooms.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Jack Davis, - Oneida No.326.

This young man obtained his senior Matriculation last summer at Port Colborne High School, and now desires to attend McMaster University in order to finally teach.

While it is appreciated that the general policy has been not to help Indians living off the Reserves, - this office is rather of the opinion there should be exceptions, and this case is one of them.

As you know the population of the Six Nations Reserve is now over 6,000 persons, and as a result with only a limited amount of land available more and more some of our Indians must seek outside employment.

In this case, this young applicant's father owns no land, so he was forced to obtain outside employment, and since the war has been steadily employed at the International Nickel Plant at Port Colborne. As an unskilled workman with a family of four all under age, - he has not been able to save anything to support a son at University, and you will appreciate is actually not in such favourable circumstances as many of our families living on the Reserve, owning land, whose children we have assisted by grants for years, who have no rent to pay, and whose incomes earned on the Reserve are exempt from direct taxation.

Consequently this office is inclined to the opinion that this young man, having gone so far and proved his ability, should receive and deserves our help, and he may prove to be the type we may be glad to get eventually into the Indian Service.

The writer knows this family well as they frequently visit the Reserve, and this young man often sang at our School Concerts and other public events as he had a remarkable treble voice, and also sang over the radio.

While it is probably a wise policy not to assist Indian children going to High School in outlying municipalities, as they are entitled as residents to receive such education, and should not need any assistance.
assistance from the Department, - in going on to University there are expenses of a much greater nature, and it is probably more fair to help them, as being Indians they have little chance of getting consideration, help or credit from any other source.

This office recommends a grant of $300.00, and would appreciate an early reply, as the term will soon commence, and this young man must know what he can plan.

Lt.-Col.E.F.Randle,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

This will acknowledge your File 420-32-3 (E.1) of the 20th of October with reference to the approval of the various school grants, and this office appreciates your action in the matter.

With regard to the two Miller boys attending the Fort Erie Bible School, you are advised that according to the statement we have from the School authorities, the total cost per pupil for a year, including board and lodging, tuition, etc., is $274.50. This office turns over to the School authorities the school grant we receive of $100.00, - which is the only contribution the parents or the pupils make, as this family are desperately poor and cannot pay anything other than the grant afore-mentioned.

This leaves the sum of $174.50 per pupil outstanding to the school, and this office in our previous letter wished to ascertain from you whether the Department would be responsible for this amount, - as on the basis of the tuition fees paid the regular High Schools, this sum is not very much greater.

It might be added that Mrs. Miller, the mother of these two boys, is a deeply religious woman and that is the reason the parents wished the boys to attend this School as they feel they get a better form of training there than by attending the ordinary High School.

Mrs. Miller was a former teacher on the Reserve, and has been a supply teacher for us at various times.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,

Provincial IODE To Offer Scholarship To Indian Student

By Marilyn Lamborn
Canadian Press staff Writer

HAMILTON—A new $100 scholarship to an Indian student planning to attend Normal School was announced yesterday by the education secretary of the Imperial Order Daughters of the Empire, Ontario chapter.

More than 800 delegates attending the three-day annual meeting were told by Mrs. L. L. Skuce that the provincial chapter would offer the scholarship. It goes to the student from the six nations or Mississauga reserves who obtained the highest standing and intended to become a teacher.

She said the provincial IODE had spent $35,064 on education during last year, $7,762 more than the previous year.

Spends Double

Mrs. T. E. Briant of Welland, welfare convener, announced Ontario chapters had spent $92,967 on welfare work last year, almost double the amount spent the year before.

"Gradually our members are realizing the great importance of health, and stress is being placed on the promotion of health rather than on the distribution of food and clothing," she said.

IODE naturalization greeting cards were presented to 1,454 new Canadians during the year. Mrs. G. L. Hamilton of Windsor, immigration convener, reported. Mrs. Allan D. Hollinsake of Hamilton, treasurer, reported $293,851 was raised by the Ontario chapters last year and $273,872 spent.

15,344 Members

"Ontario now has 13 municipal chapters, 390 primaries, 18 junior lodges, total of 1,067 chapters," said Mrs. M. B. Somers of Tillsonburg, organizing secretary. "The total membership is 16,344, an increase of 356 over last year."

Mrs. Henry T. Ross, Jr., Barns, said Echoes, the order's magazine, now had 14,506 subscribers. Mrs. C. F. Washington of Walkerton said $538 was spent on the order's work in India. Mrs. Percy Downey, Port Arthur, said there were 2,683 Empire correspondence links last year.

Mrs. W. N. Smith of Sudbury reported that chapters had contributed $8,459 to the endowment fund, but she urged further contributions to complete the fund by the Queen's jubilee in 1950.

"Hospitalization of veterans is becoming more centralized as DVA hospitals are transferred from military jurisdiction to civic enterprise," said Mrs. J. J. Watt of Toronto, welfare convener and president. "However, there is no lessening in our conscientious devotion shown in our well-planned visiting program."

Mrs. Watt said more than one-quarter of the $14,067 raised for ex-service work was contributed through the Canadian Legion Poppy Day Fund.

Ontario chapters spent $128,281 on post-war service work during the last year, it was shown by the report of Mrs. J. B. Smart of Watertown.

At the opening sessions, Mrs. F. P. McCurdy of Toronto, national president, said the 32,000 women in the IODE must use their power and influence to uphold the "individual freedom which is threatened in every democracy."

The provincial president, Mrs. Cecil L. Brown, Hamilton, warned delegates they must be vigilant so they would not be "lured by the glittering sophistry of Soviet subversive propaganda."

I am in receipt of your recent letter with reference to payment to Edward Tobicoe for his services as truant officer on the New Credit Reserve.

Owing to the reduction in our appropriation it was decided to dispense with the services of truant officers throughout the Dominion and we communicated with you last spring with regard to the truant officers' services on the Six Nations Reserve suggesting that the R.C.M.P. be secured. Dear Colonel Randle:

With reference to our conversation about the truant officer on the Six Nations Reserve, I discussed the matter with the responsible officials and it was found that the only possible increase we can allow is in the mileage allowance. I should appreciate your advising if this arrangement is satisfactory to you.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

I would like the situation clarified regarding the truancy of Indian children attending Deseronto Public School also Milltown and Shannonville.

I do not know what financial arrangements you have made with these schools but it would appear from the quarterly accounts submitted to this office that tuitions are on monthly bases.

As you are aware there is no truant officer on this Reserve and in taking the matter up with the white authorities, they claim that it is our problem not theirs and further that they have no right to an Indian Reservation. I have just had brought to my attention a young girl from whom we pay tuition at the Deseronto Public School who has been absent for the past two weeks but no report has been made to me from either the Deseronto Public School or the local Chief of Police. I just happened to stumble on it through talking to this girl's grandmother. Incidentally this girl has been an irregular attendant all spring.

As far as I can see no one is taking any responsibility for the attendance of Indian children at these three public schools and yet the Department pays full tuition fees for them all.

While it is possibly too late to do much about this matter before the end of the current term, I would like to have your views regarding the coming school year on this very important matter.

This also brings up another point. No doubt the white schools will be opening on September 3rd whereas our Reserve day schools do not open until Oct.1st. Will you kindly advise whether you wish the Indian children to start the fall term at these outside schools in September or October.

Yours very truly,

H. H. Jones,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of May 30 regarding the truancy of Indian children attending Deseronto Public School, also Milltown and Shannonville.

It is difficult to decide what can be done about ensuring regular attendance of these children and on the other hand our funds are so limited that it is a waste of money to pay for their education at white schools if they do not attend regularly.

No doubt you can obtain the attendance figures for the quarter ended June 30 and the only solution I can think of at the moment is to check these returns carefully and any child who did not attend for at least 80% of the time during the June quarter should not be allowed to return to the school for the academic year 1940-41. Parents or guardians and the teacher of the white school should be notified accordingly.

Very careful consideration has been given to the suggestion regarding an increased allowance to the constable in order to ensure that he will perform truant officer's duties. Although the officials are very sympathetic to this recommendation it has been found impossible to put it in effect due to present regulations governing appointments.

Yours truly,

Mr. H. M. Jones,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

MEMORANDUM:

- Dr. McGill -

I beg to submit the following report covering my visit to the Tyendinaga Agency on May 26th and May 29th.

The Department pay annually a moderate fee to school sections surrounding the Reserve for the education of Indian children which management appears most satisfactory. It is difficult to understand, however, why white pupils attending Indian schools are not charged a similar fee to be paid by the responsible township or municipality. A white tenant with say four children coming from the township to rent a small Indian farm at a rental of perhaps $75. per year, creates a considerable loss to the Department in so far that the rental is usually paid to an absentee Indian and they educate the tenants children. This question shall be discussed at greater length in the office in due course.

W.S. Arneil,
Inspector for Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed Voucher No. 204 for $33.00 in favour of Mary M. Hawley, Sec-Treas., Public School Board, Deseronto, Ont. and being for tuition fees for the month of September, 1941, for Indian pupils from Tyendinaga Reserve attending that school.

I would like to bring to your attention the fact that the children of Elgin Moses and Abel Green in attending the Deseronto School have a distance of approximately one mile to go and that the Eastern Day School is about one and one-third miles from their homes. The children of Murney Maracle have about one mile to the Deseronto Public School and are distant a mile and one-half from the Eastern Day School.

The children of Peter Whalen, a white tenant on the reserve and living on the adjoining property to Murney Maracle, attend the Eastern Indian Day school. There are four Whalen children attending the Indian school.

While the seating capacity at the present time would not allow for eleven more pupils that are attending Deseronto Public school to be transferred to Eastern Indian Day school, I would consider that if the white pupils are removed from this Indian school it would allow accommodation there for the children that are now attending in Deseronto and none of these Indian children would have a greater distance than one and one-half miles from the Indian school. Miss Stoddart the teacher does walk this distance daily in attending her duties.

The same condition exists at the Shannonville end of the reserve and should be thoroughly examined in the future to lessen the tuition costs of Indian pupils attending white schools where school space is available to send them to Indian Schools.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 19th instant enclosing voucher for tuition fees for Indian children of the Tyendinaga Reserve attending the Deseronto Public School during the month of September, 1941. This account will be paid.

Very careful consideration has been given to the contents of your letter and the Department agrees with the recommendations that you have made.

It must always be kept in mind that in our opinion the funds voted by Parliament are for the education of Indian children and not for the education of white children. However, we do not wish to unduly interfere with the children's school work and consequently it has been decided that no change will be made until the end of the current quarter.

You should notify Abel Green, Murney Maracle and Elgin Moses that it is expected that their children will enroll as pupils of the Tyendinaga Eastern Day School on January 5, 1942, the date on which Indian day schools re-open after the Christmas holidays. They should further be informed that after the end of December, 1941, no further payment will be made for the education of their children at the Deseronto White School.

Mr. A.D. Moore,

Deseronto, Ont.

Dear Sir:

On October 3rd I did submit to the department voucher No. 162 for $36.00 in favour of Dr. H. E. Eckardt, Shannonville, Ont. being tuition fees for Indian pupils at Shannonville Public School for September, which Dr. Eckardt reports he has not as yet received payment. Your early consideration in payment of this voucher is requested.

To give the Department some idea of the situation concerning Indian children attending the Shannonville and Milltown Public schools, which schools receive tuition fee payment from the Department, I am enclosing a rough sketch of the Western end of the reserve, showing the location of the homes of these pupils, relative to the white schools they attend and the location of the Western Indian Day school.

Enclosed also find a statement showing the parents, number of children and the distance they are from the white and Indian schools. All children have to traverse the main roads shown by the arrows.

The enrollment at Western Indian Day school at the present time is 12 pupils and it could accommodate 30 or all those resident on the York Road and near Milltown. Children living near the Bay of Quinte are too far from an Indian Day school to be forced to attend the Western school and it would also seem an injustice to force the Milltown pupils to go to the Indian school when they are within a couple of hundred yards of another school, which would leave the children of Gordon Maracle and Hubert Brant to be transferred, as both are on a main road that is kept open the year around, providing the Department approves of such action, which certainly will not meet with the approval of the Indians who are objecting strenuously against the order to remove their children from the Deseronto Public school.
The present location of the Western Indian Day school is far from the ideal spot or centre of population at the present time, but may have been when it was erected and as Indians move about considerable. As the population is now located this school should be on the York Road in the vicinity of lots 8 or 9 and a right of way secured from Herbert Brants to the York Road, running across the farms between the two roads and such a school would have saved the paying of any tuition fees and all could have attended an Indian school without too much distance or hardship.

At the present time there are five white pupils attending Eastern and three attending Central Indian Day schools and those attending Eastern have been instructed to remove their children at the end of the month of December. This would leave only three white children attending any Indian school at the present time thereby eliminating any proposed saw-off in the payment of tuition fees with a white municipality.

It is suggested that in the future that clauses be included in any leases granted to whites, that they must pay school tuition fees of $2.00 a month per pupil for any of their children that attend an Indian school, during the term of their lease and failing to pay their children would be barred from the school. Such a fee to be chargeable to those tenants having children of a school age and not to persons without children or not of school age.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

In your letters 103-34 of November 22nd, and December 20th, definite instructions have been given this office concerning the payment of future tuition fees on behalf of Indian children attending white schools, and for the removal of white children from the Eastern Indian Day School.

I would wish to advise you that there are three white children attending Central Indian Day School being two of Perry C. Badgley's, tenant under lease 757, and one of Raymond McKenzie's, tenant under leases 799 and 831.

The farms occupied by these white tenants are situated on what is known as the Ridge Road in Concession A, and they are distant, in the case of McKenzie over four miles, and in the case of Badgley over five miles from the school. Mr. Badgley has appeared at this office inquiring if any change is contemplated by the Department with regard to the attendance of his children at the Central School, maintaining it is an impossibility for him to send them elsewhere. He also states that he paid school tax on his previous lease amounting to $40.00 per annum when he had no children of school age, and considers he is entitled to some consideration in regards to the present attendance of his two small children.

If the Department contemplates any change in connection with these three children, I would be pleased to receive your instructions at an early date, as after the first of the year they will be the only white children on the Indian Reserve going to an Indian School.

Your obedient servant,

Deseronto, Ont. January 8th, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed Voucher 268 amounting to $149.04 in favour of Mary M. Hawley, Secretary of Board of Education, Deseronto, and being for tuition fees for December quarter for Indian pupils attending at the Deseronto High School.

This account again makes charges for the two children of Mark Maracle, who is as I reported when submitting accounts for September fees on November 27th last, a permanent resident of Deseronto, where he owns property and pays school tax. Charges to the amount of $53.76 should be deducted from the amount of the enclosed voucher.

I have also learned from Miss. Hawley that the Dept. paid voucher #209 in its entirety, whereas $20.16 should have been deducted as charges made for the children of Mark Maracle. This amount should also be deducted from the enclosed voucher as being overpayment of fees for September month.

With reference to your letter 103-34 of December 3rd I would advise that I have interviewed Herbert J. Brant and Earl Green, parents of the other three children attending High School and they have advised me that they had not procured the permission of any persons to place their children in high school and did not consider such permission necessary, as it had never been demanded by other Agents in the past. These Indians are also of the belief that when they surrendered the land on which the High School is built to the Town of Deseronto it was understood at that time that all Indian children would be privileged to attend at the Deseronto school. This belief is also carried by some of the Band Council, although there is nothing in the surrender to bear out this contention.

Herbert J. Brant appeared before the Council meeting yesterday complaining that never before I came here was it necessary that an Indian of their band had to make application to the Department through this office to be allowed to send their children to Deseronto High School and considered that I was overstepping my authority in asking him on whose authority he placed his child in Deseronto school, with fees to be paid by the Department. From the contention of Herbert Brant and some members of the Council, it would appear that they have always been allowed to do much as they liked in this matter in the past.

As Catherine Brant, Donald and Vernon Green are reserve residents I recommend that they be allowed to complete their attendance at High School for the present academic year, their tuition fees to be paid by the Department and that in future no fees will be paid unless the admission of the pupil receives the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Dear Sir:

Apparently he is entitled to the same consideration as other residents of Deseronto.

Ottawa, May 9, 1942.

Memorandum:

Mr. Hoey,

I visited the Tyendinaga Reserve on May 6 and 7.

All members of the Council seemed quite reconciled to the fact that it was not our intention to pay tuition fees for children attending the two white schools on the west side of the reserve; namely, Shannonville and Milltown.

However, there are probably two or three families on the western side of the reserve whose children will have to permit to attend Milltown due to the fact that a large swamp near their house would make it necessary for them to travel between 3 and 4 miles to reach the Western school. If we insisted on the children from these few families attending the latter school there is no doubt that they simply would not attend. Indian Agent Moore will advise us later regarding the names of the families concerned.

I also had considerable discussion with the Indian Agent regarding the clause in the old leases of the white tenants providing for payment of "School Taxes." The agent seemed to be under the impression that all of the leases of white tenants called for payment of school tax. However, I remember that this question came up about three or four years ago and at that time it was decided that when leases were renewed there would be no clause in them regarding school tax. On checking with the Treasury Branch I find that there are very few of the white tenants whose leases now call for payment of school tax and when these particular leases expire there will be no clause in the new lease regarding school taxes. He agent mentioned specifically the case of Parr Badgely who, he stated, was paying a school tax of approximately $6.00 a year. I find in the Treasury Branch that Mr. Moore is mistaken in this regard and I am writing to him to that effect.

Philip Phelan,
Chief Training Division.

Dear Mr. Pratt:

I have been interviewed by Mr. Perry Badgley, R.R. #1, Deseronto, who rents a farm belonging to Dan H. Maracle being part of lot 21, Concession "A", Township Tyendinaga, on a Mohawk Indian Reserve. Mr. Badgley has rented this farm for approximately eleven years at an annual rental of $500.00.

He has been advised by Mr. Moore, the Indian Agent, at Deseronto, that regulations have been issued preventing his children from attending the school on the Reserve. This will result in his being forced to drive the children six miles to and from Deseronto; they are three-quarters of a mile from the Indian school. Mr. Badgley does not feel that he can drive this distance on account of the restriction on gasoline and rubber, as the two trips would estimate approximately twenty-four miles. His lease expires February 1st, next year, and he would like to renew his lease provided permission could be granted for his children to attend the Indian school.

Mr. Badgley tells me that there are very few white children on the Reserve who are in the position of his, as the majority of them live in the easterly end of the Reserve and, consequently, it is easier for them to go to Deseronto than to the Indian school.

He would, therefore, be very grateful if you can ascertain the background of the regulations concerned and see whether or not an exception could be made or an amendment added which would permit Mr. Badgley's three children to go to this school. He would be very glad to pay school tax or any other moderate assessment for this privilege. If this arrangement could be made it would be very beneficial for all concerned.

Thanking you, with kind regards, I remain,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) McLean Haig.

Dear Sir:

Under instructions given in Mr. Hoey's letter of January 6th 1942, file 103-34, Mr. Perry Badgley and Mr. Raymond McKenzie, white tenants on the reserve, were advised that their children could not attend Central Indian Day school after the end of last June term and that they would have to make other arrangements for their children.

To date neither Badgley or McKenzie have made any other arrangements and desire to have their children continue to attend at Central School. While McKenzie did not personally pay any school tax in past years, his father with whom he resided did pay when he had no children attending school. The case of Badgley has been brought to the attention of the department on previous occasions and this man paid $200.00 in school taxes when he had no children attending school.

Mr. Hoey visited this Agency today and requests that I bring to your attention the question of allowing these three children to continue to attend at Central School and while I am little concerned in the case of McKenzie, I feel some consideration should be given Badgley, who occupies the best farm on the reserve containing 250 acres, is a good workman, pays $500.00 annual rental to an aged Indian owner, whose farm will possibly lie idle if Badgley has to remove, as he is resident at least five miles from a white school. On account of this situation and because no white school is available for Badgley it is suggested that he be allowed to continue to send his two children to Central School during the term 1942-43 and no precedent will be created as with the exception of McKenzie and Badgley all other white tenants are near to white schools that entail no hardship to them. McKenzie's lease runs out in 1943 and he should have the same privilege and his lease not renewed at that time, unless he makes other arrangements for the education of his child.

Philip Phalen, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, with reference to allowing the children of Mr. Perry Badgley and Mr. Raymond McKenzie to attend the Tyendinaga Central School. I was under the impression that all the officials had decided not to allow white children to attend Indian schools in future. Recently we received from the Minister's office a letter which had been forwarded to them on behalf of Badgley's children and in our reply we stated that favourable consideration could not be given to their attending the Central School.

You refer to the amounts which Badgley claims to have paid for school taxes. I believe that you understand the circumstances under which these were collected and, although a portion of the amount received was credited to band funds, it was never used in connection with the cost of education on the Tyendinaga Reserve. I am inclined to feel that if we change our mind again we will be obliged to provide educational facilities for these children and children of other white tenants as long as they lease land on the reserve. I will discuss the matter further with Mr. Hoey when he returns to the office next week and write to you again.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

This office recently received a visit from Mr. C. Sager, Chairman of the Deseronto School Board, in connection with the payment of tuition fees for five Indian Children, residents of Tyendinaga Reserve, who are attending the High School here.

I have your letter of December 6th in connection with pupils from Tyendinaga Reserve attending Deseronto High School and in so far as it refers to the second paragraph of that letter I would wish to more fully explain the cases of these three pupils mentioned.

Lorraine Brant one of these pupils passed her entrance exams in June 1942; she is the daughter of Hubert Brant who has five younger children attending day school. Brant lives within one mile of Shannonville and in September arranged that his child would attend Shannonville Continuation School and the school board of that Village agreed to accept her without any fees being charged. In December 1942 the teacher of the Shannonville School took ill and Lorraine continued her studies at the Deseronto High School and travelled daily by bus, a distance of 12 miles and the Deseronto School Board did not charge her any fees from December 1942 to June 1943 and this girl passed into the 2nd form with very high marks. When the Deseronto High School opened on October 1st 1943 (Shannonville School having discontinued High School grades) Lorraine enrolled at that school and according to the Principal is a very adept pupil. While the mother of this girl approached me in September 1943 concerning assistance from the Department in the payment of fees, I advised her that possibly the school board would not be charging any, as they had not done so for the six months of the year 1942-43 and when she was advised by the board of these charges and their amount and needed help I would then be prepared to submit a report to the Department for your consideration as to a grant being given. This girl has shown an earnest desire to attend school and the parents have considered transportation costs that they have been paying themselves and if and when the local school board take some definite action concerning fees and mean to levy the same, a grant from the department would certainly be recommended by this office, to the amount of the fees as set by the school board.
Ellwood Brant, 15 year old son of Ex-Chief John A. Brant passed his entrance with honours in June 1943 and is now going to Deseronto High School. Brant has four children in all, two going to school and two over school age and lives 9 miles from Deseronto. This parent applied to me in August last with reference to assistance if fees were to be charged for his son and I advised him that should the High School Board levy fees I was prepared to place his application for assistance before the Department. Ellwood from Oct 1st to Nov 30th did cycle each day from his home on the reserve and since December 1st has been boarding in Deseronto with relatives, going home on week ends. While Ellwood had some earning capacity last summer the cost of his books, cycle, board would use this up and if fees were to be charged for this boy I was quite prepared to recommend to the Department that he be given a grant of three-quarters the amount of such fees.

Phyllis Green, 14 year old girl of Abel Green, passed her entrance in June 1943 and is now going to Deseronto High School. Green has seven children of school age and under and lives on the reserve within one mile of the High School. The parents of this child at no time contacted this office concerning her enrollment or assistance in a tuition grant. While Green did not apply, had he done so I was quite prepared to recommend to the Department that Phyllis receive a grant to half the fees that would be charged by the board for this girl, and while there were no transportation or board costs in this case, Green has a large family with limited earning capacity himself and would have been deserving of some assistance.

In your letter you request applications for grants by the end of July, which would be hardly possible if all school boards are like the Deseronto High School Board, in that they cannot make up their minds if they are going to charge tuition fees for Indian children or not, for after I received your letter I contacted the Chairman as to whether the board had taken any action to set the amount of fees for Indian children and he advised me that although a meeting was held by the board in December, the question did not even come up at the board meeting and fees are generally assessed in accordance with the enrollment on a per capita basis. If no fees are charged for Indian children then I would consider no grants necessary as I believe all Indians can arrange for transportation themselves as is now being done by Norway Maracle and Frank Claus, whose girls passed their entrance last June and are attending Belleville High School on arrangements made by their respective parents.

A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 14, 1943.

Mr. A. D. Moore, Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ont.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 9th instant and have noted with interest the additional information contained therein.

I may state that we have, in our parliamentary appropriations from year to year, a comparatively small amount for the payment of tuition grants and for the care of delinquent and incorrigible Indian pupils. During the months of July and August, thousands of requests reach the Department for tuition grants. These requests come from school principals, Indian agents, missionaries, etc. All requests are carefully reviewed and a decision reached in each case. You can readily see, therefore, how important it is that requests for tuition grants from the Tyendinaga reserve should reach us late in July or early in August. Unless such requests reach us at that time, it will be simply impossible to consider the claims of pupils from your agency, regardless of how deserving they may be.

In the case of the pupils referred to in your communication - Lorraine Brant, Ellwood Brant and Phyllis Green, may I suggest that you discuss the case of these pupils with the Chairman and Secretary of the Deseronto High School Board. Despite the fact that our funds for this year have been allotted, a sincere attempt will be made by the officials here to meet the tuition costs of these students, on your recommendation. It is important, however, and of course very desirable, that a decision in respect to the matter should be reached at an early date.

I have for acknowledgement your letter of January 21st in connection with the attendance of Joan Claus, daughter of No.684 Frank Claus, Tyendinaga Reserve, who is a pupil of the Collegiate Institute, Belleville, Ont. and would enclose Voucher 270 amounting to $54.26 in favour of the Board of Education in payment of fees from September to the end of December 1943.

Frank Claus the father of this girl was admitted to the Ontario Hospital, Kingston, July 1st 1943 and shortly after his wife procured employment at the Deacon Shirt Co., Belleville, and up until December 22nd, commuted daily by car from her home on the reserve and Joan received her transportation with her. In the latter part of December, Mrs. Claus and her daughter took up light housekeeping in two rooms at 110 Station Street, Belleville, for which she pays a monthly rental.

While Mrs. Claus cannot be considered to have had a Belleville domicile previous to 1944 and therefore tuition fees would be chargeable for 1943, I do consider that if they maintain their present rooms in the future they should be exempt from future payment of tuition fees. I advised Mrs. Claus that she should continue her present domicile in Belleville as in my opinion it was a more satisfactory way to live than commuting daily, both for Mrs. Claus and for the school pupil Joan, and also would be less liable to injure their health. While Mrs. Claus must be complimented for the way she is maintaining herself and child, she could give no reason for not contacting this office or making application for assistance for tuition fees, when she enrolled her daughter last September.

Norway Maracle has two daughters attending school in Belleville, the eldest Norma has been going for some time and is in 12th grade. The youngest girl Alma commenced last September and is in 9th grade.

(over)
Mrs. Maracle advises me that at the time of enrolling these girls, she was informed by the Principal that there would be no fees, although they offered to pay if necessary, on account of both girls being domiciled in homes in which they gave some work in return for their board and lodging; in fact the girl Norma is living with the family of Colonel Merritt, V.C.

As no fees have been requested on behalf of the girls of Norway Maracle, the matter could be let drop for the present and this industrious family congratulated in the manner in which they are seeing that their children procure higher education.

REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF SEPTEMBER, 1944

Schools:
Nearly all pupils plus new ones entered the two boarding schools the first week. There were 194 children enrolled at the end of the month - all appeared to be in good health. There are competent teachers in all class-rooms; manual training cannot be taught at either school as no instructors available, at present.

The Principal of Old Suns is frog jumping between Blackfoot Reserve and Elkhorn School, Manitoba, and he taught manual. The Principal of Crowfoot lost his mechanic and growing more grey hairs! He has another man arriving in October. Both schools had good crops, all harvested. Three Indian boys entered Gleichen High School - in Grade 9 on October 2nd, by arrangements made this month. A number of ex-pupils girls are working in hospitals, boarding schools and hotels as seamstresses or maids, while one girl is a stenographer in the air force and one boys is stenographer in this office. This is mentioned because such facts are not generally known.

Please find enclosed voucher No. 89 to the amount of $83.00 in favour of the secretary of S.S.5, Tyendinaga and being for tuition fees for Indian pupils attending this white school, made necessary on account of Western Indian Day School being closed from the inability to procure a properly qualified teacher for the Reserve School.

D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Schools: The school attendance during June quarter has been fairly good, but in spite of the efforts of this office and local Reserve organizations, the attendance has never been brought to a maximum and it is anticipated some better results will be obtained in the future on account of family allowances being paid to Indians. The teachers report a moderate number of cases of head and body lice, also the odd case of skin disease in which it has been necessary to order the children home for attention and treatment. Four pupils from Eastern, all that tried, have passed their Entrance examinations and two of these at least have expressed a desire to attend the local High School; the other two are making their own arrangements to attend Vocational School at Belleville. Two pupils from Central passed their Entrance Exams and one girl is expecting to continue to High School at Deseronto. As previously reported, the co-operation from the R.C.M.P. and Special Constable in their duties as truant officers has been poor, lack of which can be attributed to the extra duties placed on the police on account of the war, which limits the time available for duties on the Reserve. It is expected these officers will give more supervision from this time on and that the parents will be closely checked in connection with the poor and irregular attendance of children of school age. For two days, June 19 and 20, senior pupils of all Reserve schools attended the Homemakers Club convention and heard addresses concerning Family Allowances, nutrition and medical care, school attendance, etc., from which they should derive considerable benefit in future. Manual training and sewing work at Eastern school has progressed well but has lagged some at Mission and Central schools, due partially to the indifference of the teachers in not procuring materials as was authorized. It is suggested that some definite graduation ceremony be established annually for Indian pupils who pass their Entrance examinations and at this gathering the children receive their entrance diplomas and also be capped and gowned. Such a procedure would be of some incentive for pupils to at least get their entrance and presentation of their certificates could be made by an official of the Department or some prominent local school inspector or public official. Gowns and mortar boards are inexpensive and could be supplied by the Department on a loan basis and be available yearly.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent,

The status of this girl is complicated and has not been thoroughly established in that she is the illegitimate daughter of No. 820, Stella Claus of the Mohawk Band. The mother gave the child, when quite young, in adoption to Roma Hennon, who has raised and schooled her on the Indian Reserve. Roma Hennon is the widow of a white man and therefore has no Indian status, although she has made her home with her aged mother, Mrs. Margaret Culbertson, on the Reserve for over ten years.

When taking possession of the child, she changed her name from Claus to Hennon and no legal adoption was made through a court that permitted this. Mrs. Hennon now advises me that she is taking the necessary action to have this child legally adopted in a Court of Law and the point is—"what would be the status of the child if legally adopted"; would she be entitled to Band membership as the illegitimate child of Stella Claus, or, would her adoption by a Court give her the status of Roma Hennon, who is not a Band member. If, as an illegitimate child, Freda becomes a member of the Mohawk Band, I would recommend that she receive a tuition grant to attend High School and would ask your early consideration.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

Schools:

Due to Western School being kept closed, about 32 children are attending at the Shannonville and Milltown white Public Schools where their fees at $2.00 a month per pupil are being paid by the Department and this procedure meets with the approval of most of the parents and the pupils themselves, as they have much less distance to travel to go to school and seem perfectly satisfied to continue the present arrangement. I do believe it to the advantage of these children to be associated with white children as it would broaden their prospective and training to their future advantage. The attendance at the agency schools has been quite fair during the Fall term. Cod Liver Oil has been supplied all schools and is given the pupils under the direction of the teachers. A number of pupils have been absent from school due to skin diseases and the nurse is eventually getting these cleaned up. There were many cases of head lice reported at the time of the nurse's visit and these are also receiving attention. The Mohawk Agricultural Society have appropriated $25.00 as prizes for the Fair in the Fall of 1946 and arrangements will be made to compile a prize list so that the school children can show exhibits of school work, including sewing and manual training and the Department will be asked to supply the materials necessary for such vocational work.

Ottawa, July 16, 1946.

Mr. A. D. Moore, Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ontario.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the Tyendinaga Western School.

In view of the contents of your letter, the Department agrees that it would not be advisable to re-open this school for the academic year 1946-47. The Indian children who should attend this school may continue at the white school at which they were present during the past academic year. Payment will be allowed at the rate of $2.00 per pupil per month.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

26th July, 1946.

The Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We submit herewith report on the students of the Indian Reserve who attended our High School January 1st, 1946 to June 30th, 1946:

Brant, Lorraine was promoted from Grade 12 to 13. A good student who is often absent to help at home.

Greene, Phyllis was promoted to Grade 12 with a condition in Algebra. She is a hard working student and regular in attendance.

Greene, Eugene Left school in May and is working in Kingston. He was doing fair work in Grade 10.

Brent, Betty Left school in June as her mother was ill. She may return in the month of September if her mother's health improves. Grade 9.

Green, Ethel An excellent student. Promoted to Grade 10.

Hannon, Freda An excellent student promoted to Grade 10.

Marsden, Cedrick Left school early to work on the farm. He may return in September. A clever boy who should be kept in school.

The above reports are of our principal, A.C. Reid, a copy of which we have on our files.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

J.C. Reynolds
Vice-Chairman
